subsection.heading: 1 Introduction: organization of the chapter
subsection.p: The term ‘partial movement’ (PM) can be understood in at least two ways. If interpreted literally it refers to all constructions in which – by whatever criterion – a phrase ‘ought’ to have moved to a position P, but has in fact only been displaced to a structurally lower position. However, the generative discussion of PM often focuses on a special subcase of (apparent) scope marking for wh-phrases, which may or may not turn out to be a subcase of partial movement in the sense just introduced. This chapter tries to do justice to both interpretations of PM. However, most of the discussion is concerned with the scope-marking construction.

The chapter begins with a definition of PM, and then develops a simple typology. The next section exclusively focuses on the wh-scope-marking construction was denkst du wer kommt ‘what do you think who comes’, whereas section 3 deals with other instances of PM in the more literal sense. Apparent PM effects in child language (see, e.g., McDaniel et al. 1995; van Kampen 1997) are beyond the scope of the present chapter. In order to facilitate the interpretation of the example sentences, phrases that have undergone PM (or appear to have done so) will appear in boldface throughout this chapter. Fully moved phrases appear in italics. Wh-phrases in situ will be underlined.

subsection.heading: 1.1 Definitions
subsection.p: Partial movement (PM) contrasts with the complete execution of a movement operation. This distinction arises in the context of the idea that certain grammatical principles require the displacement of phrases from their original position to a different structural slot. This may be necessary for picking up or checking Case, for fulfilling requirements such as the Extended Projection Principle (every clause must have a subject), for reasons linked to scope, etc. Thus, in a language of the English type, a wh-phrase must appear in the specifier position (Spec) of the largest CP (clause) it takes scope over semantically (unless it appears in a multiple question). The wh-phrase has to move to its LF-scope position.

(1)
a. *John believes that Mary saw who?
b. Who does John believe that Mary saw t?

Movement is complete – as in (1b) – if the phrase reaches a position in which it meets the relevant requirements (who has moved to its scope position); movement is partial whenever the phrase has been displaced but its final landing site is below the relevant position. PM is thus illustrated by Bahasa Indonesian (2b), a construction in which the wh-phrase siapa ‘who’ has left its base position (in contrast to (2a)), but has not moved into the matrix clause which it takes scope over (Saddy 1991, 1992).

(2)
a. Bill tahu Tom men-cintai siapa.
Bill knows Tom loves who
b. Bill tahu siapa
yang Tom cintai.
Bill knows who FOC Tom loves
c. Siapa
yang Bill tahu Tom cintai.
who FOC Bill knows Tom loves

Of course, not every movement that places, e.g., a wh-phrase closer to the position corresponding to its scope is partial wh-movement. Thus, wh-phrases can be scrambled to a certain extent in German (cf. (3a–b)). Wen is closer to its LF-scope position in (3a) than it is in (3b) (as (3d) shows), but this movement is carried out because of whatever is responsible for scrambling – it is not related to scope taking.

(3)
a. Ich weiss nicht wann
wen
wer
t gesehen hat.
I know not when who-acc who-nom
seen has
b. Ich weiß nicht, wann wer wen gesehen hat.
c. [CP wann [IP wer [VP wen gesehen hat]]]
d. [CP wann [IP wen [IP wer [VP t gesehen hat]]]]
‘I do not know who saw whom when.’
It is thus more accurate to say that movement of Σ from A to B is an instance of partial f-movement if:

li.p: B is a typical landing site for f-movement;
B is the highest such position Σ reaches (in overt syntax);
the requirements responsible for f-movement cannot be met by Σ in B, but would be met in C, such that
C is higher than B; and
B does not participate in any other type of chain-merger, at least not in overt syntax.

subsection.p: Condition (a) distinguishes partial wh-movement from, e.g., wh-phrase-scrambling. Condition (b) distinguishes partial wh-movement from intermediate steps of cyclic wh-movement. Condition (c) excludes complete wh-movement. Condition (d) is added in order to distinguish partial wh-movement from constructions such as German (4) discussed by Reis and Rosengren (1992), in which wh-phrases are moved beyond their LF-scope position, but in which they nevertheless appear in a typical landing site for wh-phrases, namely, the Spec of the matrix CP. Condition (e) serves to exclude parasitic gap constructions such as (5): according to some approaches (e.g., Chomsky 1986a), parasitic gaps arise by the wh-movement of an empty operator to the Spec of, e.g., the adjunct clause. The two chains (of the empty operator and of the real wh-phrase) are, however, merged later.

(4)
Wen sag mal dass sie t liebt.
who say once that she
loves
‘Tell me who she loves.’
(5) Which books did you file t? [OP without reading t]

subsection.heading: 1.2 A simple typology of partial movement
subsection.p: Although the movement of phrases and words may serve a multitude of purposes and ends, the generative discussion of PM has focused on constituent question formation. This appears to reflect a generalization about natural languages: there are very few or no undisputable cases of partial topicalization, scrambling, relative clause formation, raising, incorporation, etc. (see section 1.2.5). The following typological remarks thus concentrate on partial movement in question formation.

subsection.heading: 1.2.1 Simple partial movement
subsection.p: The construction exemplified in Bahasa Indonesian (2b) represents the simplest type of PM: the structure involves the partial displacement of the wh-phrase only. This construction will be called simple partial movement (SPM). SPM-structures are grammatical in other Malay languages (cf. Cole and Hermon 1998b), in Kikuyu (Clements 1984), Buli (Ferreira and Ko 2000), Slave (as illustrated in (6b), see Rice 1989; Basilico 1998) and other Athabascan languages (Western Apache, Potter 1997; Babine-Witsuwit’en, Denham 2000), and in Ancash Quechua (Cole 1982b). 1

(6)
a. Raymond [Jane judeni
ri yili] kodhisho? Slave
Raymond Jane where FOC 3-be 3-know
b. Raymond [judeni Ri Jane yili] kodhishi?
‘Where does Raymond know that Jane is?’
Other languages exemplify SPM in a restricted way only. Thus, in Iraqi Arabic (Wahba 1991), SPM is restricted to infinitive complements (7).

(7)
a. Mona raadat tijbir Su’ad tisa’ad meno? Iraqi Arabic
Mona wanted to force Su’ad to help who?
b. Mona raadat tijbir Su’ad meno
tisa’ad?
c. Mona raadat meno
tijbir Su’ad tisa’ad?
d. Meno
Mona raadat tijbir Su’ad tisa’ad?

Some dialects of German and Romani (see McDaniel 1989) allow SPM in complex multiple questions only: when a wh-phrase (from the matrix clause) occupies its scope position, another wh-phrase from a lower clause can or must move to the highest still vacant specifier position, as illustrated in (8b) for some versions of German (co-existing there with standard German (8a)), and (8c) for Romani.

(8)
a. Wer
glaubt dass sie wen
liebt?
who thinks that she whom loves
b. Wer
glaubt wen
sie
liebt?
who thinks whom she
loves
‘Who thinks that she loves whom?’
c. Ko
vakerja kaj
o Demiri khelja?
who said where the Demir danced
‘Who said that Demir danced where?’

SPM always co-exists with full wh-movement and with the wh-in-situ strategy. We may defend generalization S1 as follows: a language that allows SPM also allows full movement to the scope position and the in situ strategy in some contexts (Russian may be an exception, though) 2 – not necessarily the one in which a SPM shows up. For the contexts in which SPM is possible, we can also defend S2 by stating that the wh-phrase might have also stayed in situ. The validity of S2 is supported, e.g., by the array of facts of Iraqi Arabic, where (wide scope) wh-elements in situ are restricted to non-finite complement clauses, just as SPM is. Of course, the reverse of S1 does not hold: there are languages like Duala in which wh-phrases may either stay in situ or undergo complete movement, but in which SPM is not acceptable (Epée 1976; Biloa 1993; Sabel 1996a, 2000). Likewise, the reverse of S2 does not hold: there are contexts in which wh-phrases are tolerated in situ but in which SPM is ungrammatical (see, e.g., Cole and Hermon 1998b).
If a language tolerates SPM, it also tolerates wh-elements in situ and allows full wh-movement.
If a construction is grammatical with SPM, it can also be constructed with a wh-phrase in situ.

subsection.heading: 1.2.2 Partial movement with a scope-marking particle
subsection.p: In Albanian (Turano 1995), the scope of wh-phrases is marked by a particle and the wh-phrase may undergo PM, as illustrated by (9):

(9)
a. A mendon se Maria thotë se çfarë
ka sjellë burri? Albanian
Q think that Mary says that what brought her husband
b. A mendon se çfarë
thotë Maria se ka sjellë burri?
‘What do you think that Maria says that her husband brought?’

This construction can be called particle-marked partial movement (PPM). PPM also exists in Iraqi Arabic if the element sh-appearing in front of the verb in (10) and (11) is to be analysed as a wh-particle. The particle is optional if wh-in situ is grammatical as well (as in (11)), and obligatory otherwise (as in (10)).

(10)
a. Sh-tsawwarit Mona Ali raah weyn? Iraqi Arabic
Q-thought Mona Ali went where
b. Sh-tsawwarit Mona weyn
Ali raah
‘Where did Mona think that Ali went?’

(11)
a. (Sh)-raadat Mona Ali ygaabal meno?
Q-wanted Mona Ali meet whom
b. (Sh)-raadat Mona meno
Ali ygaabal?
‘Who did Mona want Ali to meet?’

PPM also seems to belong to the strategies of question formation in Passamaquoddy (see chapter 4 of Bruening 2001). SPM and PPM may co-exist within a single language (Iraqi Arabic), and so can PPM and the what-construction (Passamaquoddy). The difference between SPM and PPM corresponds to the one between wh-in-situ-languages in which the scope of a wh-phrase needs to be marked by a particle (as in Japanese) and languages in which this is not mandatory (e.g., Chinese).

subsection.heading: 1.2.3 Partial movement with scope marking by the most unmarked wh-word
subsection.p: In a considerable number of languages, the scope marker in PM is formally identical with the most unmarked simple wh-phrase, as in German (12a). It is not fully accurate, though, to call was and its counterparts in other languages scope-markers, because they can (and, in some dialects, must) appear in all Specs of CP between the ‘real’ wh-phrase and its LF-scope position, as (12b) illustrates. Of course, in (12b) the lower was does not mark the scope of wen. Let us call this construction type the WHAT-construction (WC), and was (and similar items) the what-phrase (WP), because the other terms (wh-scope marking construction, wh-expletive, etc.) are not theory-neutral. WPs will appear in capitals in all subsequent examples.

(12)
a.
was
glaubst du wen
Irina t liebt?
what believe you who-Acc Irina
loves
‘Who do you believe that Irina loves?’
b.
was
glaubst du
was
er sagt wen
Irina liebt?
What believe you what he says who Irina loves
‘Who do you believe that he says that Irina loves?’

The WC can also be found in Frisian (Hiemstra 1986), Serbian–Croatian, 3 Czech, 4 Romani (13a); McDaniel 1989), Hungarian (13b); Marácz 1989; Horvath 1997), Finnish, Warlpiri (Dayal 1994; Legate 2002, forthcoming), and older versions of Mohawk (Baker 1996). It is absent in Dutch and English. In the WC languages just mentioned, the WC always involves the partial movement of the real wh-phrase.

(13)
a. So
misline savo
filmi
o Demiri dikhla? Romani
what you-think which film Demir saw
‘Which film do you think Demir saw?’
b. Mit

hívott rel Mari? Hungarian
what they said that who-Acc called up Mary
‘Who did they say that Mary had called up?’

A WC can furthermore be found in Hindi (14a; Srivastav 1991c; Mahajan 1990), in Bangla (14b; Bayer 1996), in Kashmiri (Wali and Koul 1997), and in Marathi. The type of WC found in the Indian languages does not necessarily involve PM of a wh-phrase, since these languages tolerate wh-in-situ (see (15)). However, PM of the wh-phrase is possible or necessary if, e.g., the WP kyaa ‘what’ and the real wh-phrase would be separated by a finite-clause boundary without movement, as in (16).

(14)
a. Siitaa-ne
kyaa
socaa ki ravii-ne kis-ko
dekhaa? Hindi
Sita-Erg what thought that Ravi-Erg who saw
‘Who did Sita think that Ravi saw?’
b. Tumi

you what think who house built?
‘Who do you think built the house?’

(15)
Jaun kyaa

John what think-PR

(16)
a. Raam-ne

Raam-Erg what thinks that Ravi-Erg what said that which man came
b. Raam-ne kyaa socaa ki kOn sa aadmii ravii ne kahaa ki aayaa thaa?

In Iraqi Arabic, WC is possibly exemplified in constructions involving sh-(eno) ‘what’ – sheno is used before subjects and sh- before verbs, so maybe WC and PPM fall together in this language. See below for more discussion of the status of sheno. In those contexts where there is a choice between movement and the in situ-strategy in Iraqi Arabic, WC can be used with both, a fact that supports the view that the availability of WC is independent of PM.

Russian, Polish, and perhaps also Warlpiri differ from the other languages with a WC insofar as they seem to use the equivalent of how as their WP. However, at least (17b) may require a different analysis. For the vast majority of Polish speakers, the construction cannot be used for embedded questions (see (18), Adam Przepiórkowski, p.c.), and it is confined to a very small set of verbs like think. One may therefore wonder whether (17b) really illustrates a productive example of a WC.

(17)
a. Kak
vy dumaete kogo
ona ljubit? Russian
how you think who she loves
‘Who do you think she loves?’
b. Jak
myslisz kto
wczoraj do nas przyszedł? Polish
how think-2sg who yesterday to us came
‘Who do you think visited us yesterday?’

(18)
*Zastanawiam si
, jak
sadzisz, kto przyszedł. Polish
I wonder how you think who came

The use of the WC is also highly restricted in Russian, as Stepanov (2001) points out – it is again possible with a handful of matrix verbs only. However, Stepanov argues that these restrictions may be derived from the Case-less nature of kak. Interestingly, according to Legate (2002), the WC is rarely used in Warlpiri as well. These observations suggest that the particular choice of the WP may be important for the grammaticality of a WC. In Passamaquoddy, the WC is also formed with a wh-phrase meaning ‘what’ (keqsey), but according to Bruening (2001) the default wh-phrase would be tan.

In PPM and WC, the scope of the partially-wh-moved phrase is marked by the particle and (the highest occurence of) the WP, respectively. In other words, in PPM/WC languages explicit scope marking is a necessary condition for the well-formedness of PM.

subsection.heading: 1.2.4 Clausal pied-piping involving partial movement
subsection.p: A fourth type of partial movement in question formation can be found in Basque (Ortiz de Urbina 1990: 20) and – in a very restricted way in certain varieties of German: it involves clausal pied-piping (CPP). The wh-phrase moves to the specifier position of the complement clause (the partial-movement part). Then, the whole complement CP rather than the wh-phrase moves to LF-scope position of the wh-phrase; see (19) for Basque and (20) for German. 5

(19)
Nor
etorriko d-ela Bihar esan diozu Mireni? Basque
who come Aux-that tomorrow said Aux to Mary
‘Who did you say to Mary t will come tomorrow?’
‘that who will come tomorrow have you said to Mary?’

(20)
Wen
einzuladen würde dir Spass machen? German
who to invite would you fun make
‘Who would it be fun for you to invite?’

Aniko Liptak (p.c.) points out that Hungarian allows partial movement of a wh-phrase in a (free) relative clause if the whole relative clause moves into the matrix Focus Phrase, as in (21). The structure is grammatical only if the wh-phrase moves the relative-clause internal focus position.

(21)
?Aki hány pontot ér el megy át a vizsgán? Hungarian
who how many points scores-PV goes through the exam
‘Who are such that they pass the exam, who score how many points?’

A wh-element internal to a relative clause is also licensed in case it moves to the relative-internal FocP, and the head of the relative is a wh-phrase and moves to the matrix [Spec, FocP], as in (22). The head of the relative can be any wh-phrase, bare or complex: who, which student, etc.

(22)
Ki megy át a vizsgán, aki hány pontot ér el? Hungarian
who goes through the exam who how many points scores
‘Who are such that they pass the exam, who score how many points?’
There are, thus, some constructions that might be analyzed as CPP, but whether that is the optimal analysis has not yet been established.

subsection.heading: 1.2.5 Partial movement in constructions other than questions?
subsection.p: In the light of the fact that partial movement seems to be quite a widespread phenomenon in the context of constituent question formation, it is remarkable that there are only few convincing cases of PM in other domains of grammar. Wh-movement in question formation belongs to a family of operator movement dependencies, and one would expect to find close analogues of PM in these contexts. Likewise, A-movement might be carried out only partially.

Romani relative clauses such as (23a) (see McDaniel 1989) involve the partial movement of the relative pronoun. It is not easy to decide whether the element so that appears at the edge of the relative clause really is a WP-like element (so that (23a) would be a relative clause instance of WC) or whether it simply is the Romani complementizer (in which case (23a) would be an instance of SPM). Certain dialects of German seem to possess the same construction, but their analysis is unclear in exactly the same respect: the element marking the ‘scope’ of the relative pronoun could be a WP-element or the simple complementizer wo/was showing up in relative clauses in many dialects. So there may be instances of PM with relative clauses, but they are few, and there is no reason to assume they do not belong to the SPM type.

(23)
a. Ake o ćhavo so mislinav kas
i Arífa dikhla. Romani
here the boy what/that I think whom Arifa saw
‘Here is the boy who I think Arifa saw.’
b. Ake o ćhavo kas
mislinav so i Arífa dikhla.
here the boy whom I think that/what Arifa saw

Many southern German dialects allow constructions like (24) and (25): a clause has been moved to topic (focus) position, and within that clause a noun phrase occupies the topic position that may be considered the matrix topic or matrix focus. In this sense, the construction exemplifies CPP with topicalization. Note that most southern German dialects forbid clause-internal topicalization in an embedded clause unless that clause itself occupies the matrix topic position – a clear indication that CPP is involved. Little is known about these constructions, so I refrain from going into details.

(24)
Den
Fritz
dass du kennst ist schön.
the-Acc Fritz that you know is nice
‘It is nice that you know FRITZ.’

(25)
Den
Fritz
wenn du triffst musst du vorsichtig sein.
the-Acc Fritz when you meet must you careful be
‘You must be careful when you meet Fritz.’

English topicalization in embedded contexts such as in (26) may be taken to involve partial movement as well. One argument in favor of this position is the observation that topicalization is impossible within islands, as (26b) shows (see Ross 1986). This is reminiscent of what holds for partial wh-movement in Malay languages (see below), and is easily accounted for if the topicalized phrases move up into the matrix clause at LF, and cannot cross barriers in this process.

(26)
a. He said that revenooers, he does not like.
b. *That revenooers he does not like is obvious.

In languages which have overt focus movement, structures reminiscent of SPM can be found more often than not. The following examples from Passamaquoddy (Bruening 2001) illustrate this point. A focus phrase can stay in situ (as it does in (27)), or it can be moved to the position corresponding to its scope (28), but intermediate landing sites as in (29) are grammatical as well, as Bruening shows.

(27)
Tehpu kesiciy-uk-il wisukiluwohehtw-ac-il Maliw-ol. Passamaquoddy
only I know he-made-angry Mary-Obv

(28)
Tehpu Maliw-ol
kesiciy-uk-il wisukiluwohehtw-ac-il.
only Mary-Obv I know he-made.angry
‘I only know that he made MARY mad.’

(29)
Tehpu kkat kesiciy-ahq-il Weyn-ol
kisapem-ac-il.
only Neg she-knows Wayne-Obv she-can-rely-ony
‘She only doesn't know about WAYNE whether she can rely on him.’

Let us finally turn to A-movement and ask if any constructions involve partial movement here. Raising-to-subject constructions as in (30a) alternate with expletive constructions in which there appears in what would be the target position of movement. Interestingly, ‘partial’ movement of the nominative noun phrase is impossible in these constructions, i.e., it cannot move to the subject position of the embedded infinitive in such cases, as (30c) illustrates. This fact has been the subject of much theorizing in recent years, in particular in the minimalist program (see Chomsky 1995c).

(30)
a. A unicorn seems ___ to be ___ in my garden.
b. There seems ___ to be a unicorn in my garden.
c. *There seems a unicorn to be ___ in my garden.

Perhaps A-movement dependencies are not always incompatible with partial movement, however. Thus, passive formation alternates with there insertion, too, but now, what would be the subject in an ordinary passive does not appear in its root position (31b), but is rather fronted within the verb phrase (31c). Likewise, Exceptional Case Marking constructions such as (32) might be reconstructed as involving partial movement. Suppose the accusative case of a unicorn is checked in the specifier position of an Agreement-Object head (or a similar entity) in the matrix clause, and suppose it is true (in spite of the arguments brought forward by Postal 1974) that a unicorn has not moved to this position in overt syntax, but rather appears in the subject position of the infinitival clause. Then a unicorn has moved there without reaching its target A-position – a constellation that fulfills the criteria for PM. These observations possibly reflect topics of future research on partial movement but the data have rarely (if ever) been analyzed in this light.

(31)
a. A moose was shot ___.
b. *There was shot a moose.
c. There was a moose shot.
(32) I expect a unicorn to be ___ in my garden.

The next subsection discusses some theoretical issues. Section 2 concentrates on the WHAT-construction, because it certainly constitutes the subtype of PM that has received most attention in the past. Section 3 discusses the other types of PM.

subsection.heading: 1.3 Theoretical issues
subsection.p: If there is partial movement in the strict sense of the term, the construction poses a problem for certain theories of grammar. The problem with PM is reminiscent of the one that arises with cyclic movement. According to Chomsky (1995c) and other work in the minimalist framework, a phrase Σ can move to a position P, the specifier of the head H, only if it is attracted to that position by H. H attracts Σ only if H possesses an (uninterpretable) feature that must be checked by Σ in a specifier–head configuration.

For wh-movement, it comes close to a standard assumption that the wh-phrase and the Comp head of the CP which the wh-phrase takes scope over agree with respect to a [wh]-feature. In Chomsky (1995c), this feature attracts the wh-phrase, but it seems present in Comp only if Comp is the head of a question. In the partial-movement constructions introduced above, the wh-phrase ends up overtly in the specifier position of a CP that is not a question. Therefore the Comp head of that CP should not possess the attracting wh-feature. Thus, it is unclear what has triggered the partial movement of the wh-phrase. This (obvious) problem has been noted several times (Simpson 1995; Fanselow and Mahajan 1996; Müller and Sternefeld 1996; among many others) and a number of different solutions have been proposed. For example, the attracting feature is a categorial one that may be present independent of question semantics (see Fanselow and Mahajan 1996); the local domain for feature checking is less restricted, so a partially moved phrase may check the feature of the attracting phrase although it has not reached its specifier position (Simpson 1995, 2000); the economy condition on movement as attraction must be relaxed (Müller 1998); the attracting feature is a focus feature that is checked in the position the phrase reaches (Sabel 2000). According to Müller (1997), there is a principle that forces wh-phrases into specifier positions of CPs irrespective of the featural composition of Comp. While such approaches concede that the problem is a real one, and try to solve it by changing certain assumptions in movement theory, other models explain partial movement away, at least for certain instances. Thus, Fanselow and Ćavar (2000) argue that movement targets the scope position in SPM, but that the chain created by movement is not spelled out in the highest position of the chain. The approach proposed by Dayal (1994, 1996a, b, 2000) for the WC also implies that the wh-phrase targets its final scope position in the WC. The evaluation of these approaches depends, of course, on the array of empirical facts that need to be accounted for. We will return to the issue briefly at the end of the two following sections.

subsection.heading: 2 The WHAT-construction
subsection.p: This section offers a closer look at the WHAT-construction (WC) illustrated in (12). The first subsection summarizes the major competing analyses that have been proposed for the WC: the scope-marker analysis, the feature-movement analysis, and the two indirect-dependency approaches: the argumental and the wh-expletive version. Section 2.2 introduces a number of empirical generalizations concerning the WC. Section 2.3. attempts an evaluation of the theoretical approaches.

subsection.heading: 2.1 Competing analyses
subsection.p: This section is confined to a discussion of the WC, the major focus of this chapter. Most of the literature on PM restricts itself to an analysis of WC, with a certain emphasis on German, Hungarian, and Hindi. Two families of analyses for the WC have been proposed. In what Dayal (1994) calls the direct-dependency approach to WC, the WP was ‘what’ in (12) (repeated here) is analyzed as a ‘kind of scope marker’ for wen which has undergone PM in the sense defined above: it has left its base position, but has not moved the whole way up to its LF scope position. The direct-dependency approach goes back to Van Riemsdijk (1983b) – the theory developed by McDaniel (1989) has been a very influential version of it. Direct-dependency approaches assume that the WP and the ‘real’ wh-phrase are linked to the same chain. Therefore, the featural movement theory of Hiemstra (1986) is a direct-dependency approach as well.

(12)
Was
glaubst du wen
Irina t liebt?
what believe you who-Acc Irina
loves
‘Who do you believe that Irina loves?’

The alternative model, called indirect-dependency approach by Dayal (1994), assumes that the WP is a wh-phrase for propositional complements. It is linked to the wh-clause, in which the wh-phrase has undergone standard wh-movement to an A-bar-position that may even, in a sense to be clarified below, correspond to its (semantic/syntactic) scope. For the indirect-dependency approach, WC thus does not necessarily exemplify PM in a literal sense. There are two major versions of indirect-dependency approach, the one developed by Dayal (1994, 1996a, 2000), according to which the WP is argumental, and the version proposed independently by Horvath (1997), Mahajan (1996, 2000), and Fanselow and Mahajan (1996, 2000), according to which the wh-phrase is an expletive.

subsection.heading: 2.1.1 The scope-marking analysis
subsection.p: According to a standard view (Chomsky 1981), long-distance dependencies of wh-phrases arise in a cyclic way. On the way to their LF-scope position, wh-phrases pass through all intervening [Spec, CP] positions, as in (33).
(33) [What do you think [t1 that she said [t2 that Bill saw t3]]].

In (33), the wh-phrase and its traces form the A-bar-chain <what, t1, t2, t3>, which links the thematic position of what (= t3) to the LF scope position. In a direct-dependency approach, the WC differs minimally from long distance movement. In German (34a), the A-bar-chain <wer, t1, t2> linking the LF scope position to the thematic position is formed by movement, whereas in (34b), only the first link of the A-bar chain arises in this way – the second link is created by the insertion of an expletive-like element, the scope marking WP was: <was, wer, t2> is a chain that serves, essentially, the same function as the one created in (34a).

(34)
a. Wer
denkst du t1
dass t2
kommt?
who think you
that
comes
b.
was

(dass) t2
kommt?
what think you who that
comes
‘Who do you think will come?’

McDaniel (1989) develops an elaborate concept of wh-chains, of which expletive-like elements (scope markers), wh-phrases, and traces of movement may be part, if they appear in that order. She also notes (1989: 581) the resemblance of wh-chains with A-chains. Just as the insertion of expletive there is an alternative to overt A-movement (see (30), (31)), the insertion of WPs can be seen as an alternative to overt A-bar-movement. At least until a few years ago, this scope-marking analysis represented the standard view for German (cf., e.g., von Stechow and Sternefeld 1988; Müller 1997; Beck and Berman 2000). In its basic version, it confines itself to stating that an A-bar-chain <was, wer, t2> is formed in (34b) at S-structure, and keeps this chain at all further levels.

In an extension that takes over ingredients of some generative analyses for expletives in A-positions like there, the direct-dependency approach assumes that the wh-expletives that have been inserted at S-structure have to be replaced at the level of Logical Form, and that they are replaced by the ‘real’ wh-phrase moving upwards to its scope position at LF. Consequently, the LFs of a PM-construction become indistinguishable from the LFs of long distance movement constructions (cf. Müller 1997).

subsection.heading: 2.1.2 The feature-movement analysis
subsection.p: A very interesting version of the direct-dependency approach (anticipating some of the theoretical assumptions about movement made in Chomsky 1995c) has been proposed by Hiemstra (1986) in her analysis of Frisian. Recently, it has been revived by Cheng (2000).

Hiemstra's view can be summarized as follows. Wh-movement is always the movement of a wh-feature. Languages differ as to what needs to be pied-piped when the wh-feature moves. In long-distance wh-movement constructions, the whole feature matrix of the wh-phrase is moved, including the phonetic matrix. This gives rise to (34a). Alternatively, languages may allow that nothing undergoes pied-piping – then only the wh-feature is moved. If this option is chosen, the wh-feature has to be spelled out at the landing site. It will be realized phonetically as the most unmarked wh-expression of the language: was in German, wat in Frisian, mit in Hungarian, kyaa in Hindi, etc. This gives rise to (34b). In addition, there is an intermediate case of featural pied-piping in which person–number features (i.e., the set of formal features to which [+wh] belongs) of the wh-phrase are also moved: the feature complexes transported upwards like [wh, 3rd sg., acc] will then be spelled out as the corresponding wh-words. This gives rise to the Copy Construction CC, which can be found in Frisian (see 35a–b), German (35c–d), and a few other languages (see also Fanselow and Ćavar 2000 for a discussion).

(35)
a. Wêr
tinkst wêr't se wennet? Frisian
b. Wat
tinkst wêr't se wennet?
where/what think-you where-Comp she lives
c. Wo
denkst du wo
sie wohnt German
d. Was
denkst du wo
sie wohnt
where/what think you where she lives
‘Where do you think, she lives?’

To the extent that WC and CC are related in this or a similar way, Hiemstra's approach is the most elegant one: it is hard to see how the full wh-phrases appearing in CC can be considered to be scope markers or expletives.

subsection.heading: 2.1.3 The indirect-dependency approaches: argumental WHAT
subsection.p: While the direct-dependency approach has been the standard view for German for quite some time, research on the Hindi WC has favored a very different theory, namely, the indirect-dependency approach. This analysis was proposed first by Davison (1984), and was later taken up by Mahajan (1990), Srivastav (1991c), Dayal (1994, 1996a, 1996b, 2000). See Bruening (2001), Klepp (2002), Legate (2002), and Stepanov (2001) for indirect-dependency models for Passamaquoddy, German, Warlpiri, and Russian, respectively.

In the indirect-dependency approach, the element that is a scope marker for the direct dependency account is simply the standard wh-word for clausal complements. Thus, (36b) is analyzed as a version of (36a): was is a constituent-question phrase for CPs both in (36a) and in (36b). The relation between the WP and the CP containing the ‘real’ wh-word is then assumed to be one between a sentential expletive/pronoun and its clausal associate, as we find it in (37).

(36)
a. Was
denkst du?
what think you
‘What do you think?’
b. Was
denkst du wer
gekommen
ist?
what think you who come is
Who do you think has come

(37)
Ich habe es bedauert dass Hans
Maria
eingeladen
hat
I have it regretted that Hans Maria invited has
‘I regretted that Hans invited Mary.’
(38) What do you think? Who came?

In other words, the WC is a monosentential counterpart of (38), a construction with which it shares a number of properties; see Dayal (1996a, 1996b, 2000) and section 2.3.1. One argument in favor of this approach is that it offers an explanation for the fact that the WP of WC is always homophonous with a word that can be used to ask for propositions. In most languages with a WC, the WP is the counterpart of English what, the most unmarked wh-item and the wh-item used for asking for propositions. However, as mentioned above, if Bruening (2001) is correct, the WP of Passamaquoddy is not the most unmarked wh-item, but it is still the element asking for propositions. Likewise, the use of ‘how’ in the Russian or Polish WC seems to be related to the fact that Russian and Polish ‘how’ is a possible (though apparently not a preferred) question word asking for propositions. The connection between the WP and the wh-phrase asking for propositions also comes out clearly in Warlpiri, which has two questions words meaning ‘what’, one restricted to objects and one restricted to propositions (translated, however, as ‘how’ by Legate 2002). In the WC, Warlpiri uses the latter (see Dayal 1994):

(39)
a. Nyia
ka nga-rni?
what is-he eating
b. Nyarrpa-rlu
o-ngku yimi-ngarru-rnu?
what did-he tell-you?
c. Nyarrpa-rlu
o-ngku yimi-ngarru-rnu kuja-pala
kurdu nyarrpara-kurra ya-nu?
what did-he tell-you? where children went
‘Where did he tell you that the two children went?’
The choice of the WP is a natural consequence of the indirect-dependency approach, whereas it can be understood diachronically only in direct dependency theories.

In the indirect-dependency approaches, there is no syntactic relation between the WP and the wh-phrase in the lower clause. Rather, the WP enters a relation with the clause that (immediately) dominates this wh-phrase. The synonymy of WC-questions and questions formed by long movement thus needs to be accounted for in a different way. For Dayal (1994), the WP is a standard argumental wh-phrase. She suggests that the wh-CP in (36b) restricts the domain of propositions which was quantifies over in the following way. Let us assume, in the spirit of Hamblin (1973), that a question semantically represents the set of answers to it. Sentence (36a) can therefore be represented as &lgr;p (∃q, q a proposition & p = ^think (you, q)), or, if we assume (as Dayal does) that quantification is always restricted in natural languages, as &lgr;p (∃q (T(q) & p = ^think (you, q)), where T is a variable for an overt or covert restrictor of the matrix wh-element was. Note that the meaning of the complement clause in (36b) is &lgr;p (∃x (p = ^has-come (x))), by an appropriate interpretation for the was-CP pair, this can be made the restrictor T in the interpretation of the matrix question. We then get &lgr;p (∃q ∃x (q = ^has-come (x) & p = ^(think (you, q))) as an interpretation for (36b), and this is also a representation for the meaning of who do you think came, as required. The synonymy of the WC-question and those formed by long movement is thus a consequence of the interpretive rule for the was/es-CP pair in Dayal's system, it is not a matter of shared LFs. See Staudacher (2000) for a version of Dayal's account presupposing the Groenendijk–Stokhof type of question semantics.

subsection.heading: 2.1.4 The indirect-dependency approaches: expletive WHAT
subsection.p: The approach proposed by Mahajan (1990, 1996), taken up in Fanselow and Mahajan (1996, 2000), and also advanced by Horvath (1997), assumes indirect-dependency, too, but differs in its treatment of the role play by the WP. As in the argumental approach, the WP is related to a question complement, but the WP is an expletive in the theory proposed by Mahajan. In the latter respect, it resembles the scope-marking approach.

Mahajan (1990, 1996) does not postulate explicit semantic rules for LF-interpretation. Rather, he assumes that the expletive WP (the +wh-version of sentential expletives) needs to be replaced by its associate (the wh-clause) at LF. Thus, the LF of (36b) will be something like (40a) – which is an instance of clausal pied-piping as we find it in Basque. Since Mahajan (1996) argues that specifiers of XP can take scope over whatever XP c-commands at LF (see also Hornstein 1995), the LFs (40a) and (40b) (for a standard question formed by movement) are not identical, but yield identical semantic values. Mahajan's approach thus presupposes that there is pied-piping at LF. Note that specifiers of DPs appear to share scopal properties of their mother categories in (41), too.

(40)
a. [CP Wer
gekommen
ist] denkst du?
who come is think you
b. Wer denkst du dass t gekommen ist?
who think you that
come is
‘Who do you think has come?’
(41) [Whose mother] did you see t?

subsection.heading: 2.2.1 ‘Anti-locality’
subsection.p: The WC differs from standard scope marking in a way that has been termed anti-locality: the WP cannot appear in the clause in which the real wh-phrase originates, compare German (42) and Hindi (43) with Japanese (44) (where ka marks the scope of the wh-phrases). The Iraqi-Arabic sh-/sheno construction classified above as a PPM shares this property, a fact that suggests it may belong to the class of WC.

(42)
*Was
kommt wer? German
WHAT comes who
‘Who is coming?’

(43)
*Tum-ne kis-ko
vah kitaab
kyaa
dii Hindi
you-Erg who-Dat that book WHAT gave
‘Who did you give that book’

(44)
John-ga dare-o
butta ka sirinai Japanese
John-Nom who-Acc what Q know-not
‘Who did you give that book’
The WP and the wh-phrase (indirectly) linked to it must not be in the same clause.

Anti-locality is a straightforward consequence of the two accounts that postulate an indirect-dependency – if the WP is an expletive or argumental wh-CP linked to a proposition, there is simply no structural slot for it in (42) and (43). The validity of W1 is not an inevitable consequence of the two direct-dependency approaches, but there are ways to describe it. Essentially, one might account for W1 by assuming that wh-phrases are forced into a specifier position of CP by some constraint (Müller 1997), or by assuming that the formation of a WC is a dispreferred option (as compared to movement), which can be chosen only if movement would have to cross some kind of island: scope marking is available for long, but never for short, movement.

For German or Hungarian, i.e., for languages that have a WC and allow overt wh-movement, a natural idea is to split the wh-criterion of May (1985) and Rizzi (1990b) into two separate principles; a requirement R1 that requires that a [+wh]-Comp (or a Q head with a D-feature, or a Focus head in Hungarian) must have a [+wh]-specifier (which forces wh-movement or WP-insertion), and a requirement R2 that implies that wh-phrases must appear in the specifier position of some Comp or Focus phrase if possible (a position that need not necessarily correspond to their scope) (see Müller 1997 for such a view). R2 is violated in (42), which renders the sentence ungrammatical. R2 is also violated in grammatical multiple questions such as (45). In the Optimality-Theory account developed by Müller (1997) this difference in grammaticality between W1-violations and multiple questions is due to the fact that R2 violations cannot be avoided in multiple questions (only one wh-phrase can go to [Spec, CP] in overt syntax), while they can be avoided by choosing the simpler question wer kommt ‘who comes’ in the case of (42). In more complex examples such as (34b), the real wh-phrase fulfills R2 by moving to the lower [Spec, CP] position, whereas R1 is satisfied by was for the higher Comp; thus, a WC arises. In other words, (34) motivates the split of the wh-criterion along the lines suggested by Müller (1997).

(45)
Wen
liebt wer?
who-Acc loves who-Nom
“Who loves whom?”

Brandner (1996, 2000) accounts for W1 in a different way. Note that most wh-expressions allow both a wh- and an indefinite interpretation in German, as in many other languages (see Cheng 1997). According to Brandner, the interpretation of wen as a wh-phrase (as in (45)) or as an indefinite (as in (42a)) depends on its position. If it is in situ, the indefinite interpretation is mandatory, which, on the other hand, is absent as soon as the phrase occupies [Spec, CP]. However, a wh-interpretation for a wh-phrase in situ is licensed whenever there is a further wh-phrase in [Spec, CP], so that (46b) is indeed ambiguous. Brandner (1996) then proposes that the ungrammaticality of (42) is a consequence of the fact that the ‘scope-marker’ was does not license the wh-interpretation of wen, so that wen must be interpreted as an indefinite. The expletive scope marker is then without an associate.

(46)
a. Sie wird wen heiraten.
she will someone marry
‘She will marry someone.’
b. Wer
wird wen heiraten?
who will whom/someone marry
‘Who will marry whom?’
‘Who will marry anybody?’

The direct dependency accounts of W1 just sketched cannot be transferred easily to the Indian type of WC, as exemplified in Hindi. Here, wh-phrases simply do not have to appear in [Spec, CP] and wh-in-situ is possible. Nevertheless W1 is respected, which thus cannot be derived in the way proposed by Müller or Brandner. Note that the scope of a wh-phrase that is not part of a WC is restricted to the closest finite CP it sits in in Hindi (Mahajan 1990; see also Srivastav 1991c; Dayal 1996a); the same characterizes wh-in-situ in Iraqi Arabic (Wahba 1991) and Bangla (Bayer 1996). With the exception of Iraqi Arabic infinitives (where a WP can optionally be inserted without consequences for scope), the insertion of the WP therefore serves a function in these languages, too; the WP extends the scope of wh-phrases left in a finite CP.

In a direct-dependency approach, it may therefore be profitable to describe the grammar of the WP in terms of economy considerations: a WP may be inserted only if this contributes to establishing the scope of a wh-phrase. Given that a wh-phrase in situ automatically takes scope over the finite CP immediately dominating it in Hindi, the insertion of a WP into the same clause would not have any scope-taking function, and should therefore be avoided. If this is valid, we understand not only why W1 holds in Hindi and Bangla, we also understand why (nearly) all languages employing an unlimited wh-in-situ strategy (like Chinese) do not tolerate WC – but Latin may be an exception (Staudacher 2000). 6
A WP can be inserted only if it has a semantic effect, that is, a scope extension.

Generalization W2 is a property that is implemented easily if the WP has expletive properties. W2, or rather what it tries to explain, namely, the near absence of WCs in languages with an unlimited wh-in-situ-strategy, is not very easy to account for in models in which the WP is a full argument.

subsection.heading: 2.2.2 The WP in Spec
subsection.p: Generalization W3 seems to be straightfoward, but closer inspection reveals that it is not. For wh-in-situ-languages, W3 allows WP such as Hindi kyaa or Marathi kai (47) (Pryia Bondre-Beil, p.c.) to remain in an object position. In contrast to this, Iraqi Arabic sh(eno) must appear in clause-initial position (Wahba 1991), although Iraqi Arabic is a wh-in-situ language. Iraqi Arabic sh(eno) thus does not show the behavior of a WC.
If wh-phrases cannot stay in situ in simple questions, then a WP appears in the scope position.

(47)
Sita-la
kai
watle (ki) Ravi-ni konala
pahile? Marathi
Sita-Erg what thought that Ravi who seen-has
‘Who did Sita believe that Ravi saw?’

For languages with obligatory overt wh-movement like German, Frisian, and Hungarian, W3 requires that the WP appears in [Spec, CP] or [Spec, FP]. Wh-movement is obligatory if the specifier position of a [+wh] CP cannot be left unfilled. If there is no second wh-phrase in the clause in which the WP sits, then W3 is a trivial consequence of the grammatical property that requires that [Spec, CP] be filled. W3 goes beyond a restatement of the overt nature of wh-movement in one context, however, namely, multiple questions. Whereas certain dialects of German exclude constructions in which a WP combines with a further wh-element in the matrix clause, such constructions are possible in Hindi (48) and other dialects of German (49). The insertion of kyaa into a multiple question that relates items of two different (tensed) clauses is obligatory in Hindi – recall that the scope of a wh-phrase is restricted to the minimal tensed CP it is dominated by unless kyaa is used. Not much else needs to be said about (48a). For many speakers of German, however, there is a strong contrast between (49a) and (49b) that W3 captures: if two wh-elements compete for [Spec, CP], it is the WP that must appear in that slot.

(48)
a. Kis-ne
kyaa
socaa ki siitaa-ne kis-ko
dekhaa? Hindi
who WHAT thinks that Sita who saw
b. Kis-ne
socaa ki siitaa-ne kis-ko
dekhaa?
who thinks that Sita who saw
‘Who thinks that Sita saw who?’

(49)
a. Was
glaubt wer
wen
sie einladen wird.
what thinks who whom she invite will
b. #Wer
glaubt
was
wen
sie einladen wird
‘Who believes that she will invite who?’

Unlike W1, W3 seems to favor the direct dependency account, that is to say, if the WP was is a scope marker, it is hard to see how it could ever appear in an object position, as in (49b). This reasoning is too simple, however. First, this solution leaves it open as to why this scope marker need not appear in [Spec, C] in Hindi. Second, WPs are also licensed below the ultimate scope position, as (50b) shows. They can appear in lower [Spec, CP] positions as long as their scope is extended by a WP in a higher [Spec, CP] position, as in (50b). The ungrammaticality of (50a) suggests that argumental wh-phrases cannot, however, extend the scope of a WP (note that this sentence is acceptable with an irrelevant interpretation, see Fanselow and Mahajan 1996, 2000). The WP must always appear in a [Spec, C] position, yet its scope can be extended – but by further WPs only. McDaniel's (1989) approach captures this most straighforwardly since for her the WP enters a chain formation process with the real wh-phrase. There is a well-formedness constraint on chains that requires that a sequence of WPs (if present) must constitute the uppermost part of the chain. Müller's (1997) explanation of the contrast in (50) relates to the fact that full wh-phrases like wer in (50) can mark the scope of other wh-phrases only if the latter are in situ in most varieties of German – this a condition that cannot be possibly met in a WC. Yet, some German dialects allow scope marking by full wh-phrases for wh-phrases in [Spec, C], and so does Romani (see (8b, c)).

(50)
a. #Wer
glaubt
was
sie meint wen
Fritz liebt Fritz
who believes what she means who Fritz loves
b.
was
glaubt wer
was
sie meint wen
Fritz liebt
what believes who
what
she means who Fritz loves
‘Who believes that she thinks that Fritz loves who’?

Indirect-dependency approaches, on the other hand, claim that WPs are CP-wh-phrases, so (49b) should be no worse than (51), clearly an incorrect prediction. There are, nevertheless, ways to capture W3. According to Fanselow and Mahajan (1996, 2000), the clause hosting the ‘real’ wh-phrase must replace the expletive WP at LF. In the position it has thus reached in (52), wh can take scope over CP*, because the two authors claim that the specifier of X c-commands whatever X does. If that is combined with the assumption that the expletive WP cannot move at LF in languages with overt movement, (49b) and (50a) are ruled out because the real wh-phrase fails to be able to take its proper scope at LF.

(51)
Wer
glaubt was.
who believes what

Thus, all approaches considered so far must make sure by one mechanism or the other that the scope of a WP either corresponds to its surface position, or can be extended by further WPs only. Such a stipulation suffices to account for W3 in Dayal's version of the indirect-dependency account, too. W3 therefore does not contribute a lot that might help to decide between the various approaches; rather, it suggests that all current theories have a certain defect since they do not predict W3 in a strict sense. We should add that according to Klepp (2001) some speakers of German accept (49b) as grammatical. It seems hard to maintain a direct-dependency approach of the type proposed by McDaniel (1989) for these speakers.

subsection.heading: 2.2.3 WP sequences
subsection.p: The WC does not share all properties of standard expletive constructions. Thus, one only finds one expletive per chain in the there case (53b), but more than one WP is licensed in wh-chains in German (53a), Hungarian, and Hindi. Such a repetition of the WP is impossible in Iraqi Arabic and any other language or dialect in which WC is restricted to matrix questions. With respect to W4, the WC resembles it expletives, however (see (54)).

(53)
a. Was
denkst du
was
sie meint
was
Fritz sagte wen
Julia liebt?
what think you what she means what Fritz said who Juliet loves
‘Who do you think she believes Fritz said Juliet loves?’
b. *There seems there to appear there to be a man in the room.
(54) It was believed that it is likely that it seems that he will win.
The WP may appear in any clause separating the real wh-phrase and its LF scope position.

Generalization W4 captures a property that distinguishes WPs from standard scope markers, as mentioned above. It is not necessarily an argument against direct-dependency approaches, because the restriction of the number of expletives in A-chains to one is itself a property that calls for an explanation that seems to involve special assumptions concerning the featural composition of there. Indirect-dependency approaches have no problem whatsover in accounting for (53a), because these theories assume that the WP is a wh-CP (expletive), i.e., the wh-counterpart of it, so that the parallel we observe between (53a) and (54) is one we should expect.

There is a further difference between standard expletive constructions and WCs; economy effects favoring Merge over Move are absent in the latter. A standard expletive such as there must always be inserted immediately above the root position of its associate; it is then the expletive which moves up to the highest A-position in the chain. An A-chain involving expletives thus has the form <there, t, . . . , t, NP>, i.e., the lowest chain position must be filled by the full argument NP. The associate must not move to a higher position before the expletive is inserted (see, e.g., Chomsky 1995c for possible explanations), as (55) illustrates.

(55)
There seems t to appear t to be a man in the garden.
*There seems t to appear a man to be t in the garden.
*There seems a man to appear t to be t in the garden.

In WC, on the other hand, the real wh-phrase may undergo (partial) wh-movement before the (expletive) WP was is inserted (56) – the real wh-phrase can move to any of the intermediate [Spec, CP] positions prior to the insertion of was above the highest surface position of the wh-phrase. The same holds for Hungarian and Iraqi Arabic.

(56)
Wen
denkst du dass sie glaubt dass Fritz meint dass sie liebt?
who think you that she believes that Fritz means that she loves
Was
denkst du wen
sie glaubt dass Fritz meint dass sie liebt?
Was
denkst du
was
sie glaubt wen
Fritz meint dass sie liebt?
Was
denkst du
was
sie glaubt
was
Fritz meint wen
sie liebt?
‘Who do you think that she believes that Fritz means that she loves?’

The Hindi kyaa construction shares this property in the following sense. If a wh-phrase originating in a lower clause is to take wide scope over a higher clause, the wh-phrase may either be scrambled into the higher clause (Mahajan 1990; Srivastav 1991c), or the scope marker kyaa is used. The two options can be combined, as (57) illustrates: [partial wh-scrambling]. Thus, W5 seems to hold in general.

(57)
Raam-ne
kyaa
socaa ki ravi-ne
kyaa
kahaa ki kOn sa aadmii
aayaa thaa?
Raam-erg
what thinks that Ravi-erg
what said that which man came
Raam-ne kyaa socaa ki kOn sa aadmii ravi-ne kahaa ki aayaa thaa?
The wh-phrase may move any number of clauses up before a WP appears in the structure.

Again, the grammar of WPs is different from the one of A-expletives of the there type. Indirect-dependency approaches have a straightforward explanation for W5: for a WC to be grammatical, the clausal associate of the WP must be a wh-question, and what W5 shows is that the internal make-up of the question-associate does not matter. But W5 can be captured in direct dependency accounts with equal ease. Following Müller (1997), for instance, one can assume that wh-movement and wh-expletive insertion have similar ‘costs’ in the languages that allow WC, so that they may be combined quite freely.

subsection.heading: 2.2.4 (Im-)Mobility
subsection.p: At least for some (but definitively not for all) speakers of German, the WP was cannot be moved itself as in (58a), in contrast to what holds for there. Similarly, Hindi kyaa must be present in any intermediate clause between the real wh-phrase and the clause the real wh-phrase takes scope over, it cannot undergo (wh-)scrambling itself (58b).

(58)
a. #Was
denkst du t dass sie meint wen Fritz liebt?
what think you
that she means who Fritz loves
‘Who do you think she believes Fritz loves?’
b. *Raam-ne
kyaa
socaa ki ravii-ne kahaa ki Hindi
Raam-Erg what thought that Ravi-Erg said that
kOn sa aadmii aayaa thaa?
which man came
‘Which man did Ram think that Ravi said ___ came?’

The ungrammaticality of (58a) for some speakers of German and of its counterparts in the other languages may be related to the expletive nature of the WP, which is that expletives do not undergo A-bar-movement in general, as (59) illustrates.

(59)
a. Ich glaube dass es regnet.
I believe that it rains
b. *Es glaube ich dass t regnet.
it believe I that
rains
c. Ich glaube dass Maria es schon weiss dass sie schwanger ist.
I believe that Mary it already knows that she pregnant is
d. *Es glaube ich dass Maria schon weiss dass sie schwanger ist.
‘I believe that Mary already knows it that she is pregnant.’

Whether what we observe in (59) is responsible for (58) as well is not immediately obvious, however. If A-bar movement leaves a semantic variable as a trace, (59b, d) are ungrammatical on obvious grounds, and (58) would be semantically ill-formed for the same reason if the WP is an expletive. The problem would then be to account for the fact that a considerable number of speakers find (58a) grammatical while (59b, d) seem to be rejected uniformly. Those approaches (e.g., Müller 1997; Fanselow and Mahajan 1996, 2000) that replace an expletive WP with the wh-phrase or the wh-clause at some late point in the derivation can also make locality conditions on this replacement operation and/or the formation of expletive association pairs responsible for what we observe in (58).

Recall that partial movement of the wh-phrase is optional in Iraqi Arabic in constructions involving sh- and sheno. Thus, the wh-phrase may be separated by any number of (infinitive) CPs from sh-/sheno. In that sense, the sheno construction violates the constraint discussed in this section – but only if it is an instance of WC. Given that sh-(eno) violates other constraints on the WC as well, it is presumably more profitable to take sheno to be a true wh-scope marker in the sense of PPM.

subsection.heading: 2.2.5 The nature of the associate: a ban on yes/no questions
subsection.p: The Hindi WC strongly contrasts with the German and Hungarian one in allowing the associate of the WP to be a simple yes/no question (60b). This property is not shared by the otherwise identical kai construction in Marathi ((60c, d); Bondre-Beil, p.c.), and also not by Kashmiri.

(60)
a. *Was
denkst du ob
er kommt?
what think you if he comes
b. Tum
kyaa
socte ho ki kyaa
vo aayegaa? Hindi
you what think be that if he will-come
do you think that he will come?
c. *Sita-laa
kai
watle ki Ravi yenar ka? Marathi
Sita what thinks if Ravi comes yes–no
d. *Sita-laa

In some languages, a WC is possible only in the context of constituent questions.

Notice, however, that we already saw that the WC is rarely used in Warlpiri, and recall that the status of the how-CP construction in Polish and Russian is fairly unclear. Similarly, Bruening (2001) observes that the use of (61c) is very restricted, and requires the tag kosona al tan ‘or what?’ For this reason, he considers it doubtful that (61c) is a true scope-marking construction. Instead it seems to be a sequence of questions or an appositive. At present, it is therefore difficult to determine whether one of the two options offered by W6 is less marked than the other.

Direct-dependency accounts have not encountered serious difficulties in their attempts to account for those languages (German, Hungarian) in which the WP seems incompatible with a yes/no question. After all, the WP is claimed to be a scope marker in the chain of a wh-phrase. If no such chain is created, a WP cannot be inserted. One (minor) point left open by such accounts is why there is no comparable scope-marking for yes/no questions. This is surprising in the light of the fact that yes/no operators are in fact able to take scope out of the clause they appear in, as Chinese (62) taken from Huang (1982b) illustrates.

(62)
Ni renwei ta xi- bu- xihuan ni?
you think he li- not li-kes you
‘Do you think he likes you, or not?’

Indeed, it seems to be a language-particular property whether the scope-marker combines with wh-phrases in the strict sense only or not, because the well-formedness of Hindi (60b) would otherwise imply that proponents of the direct-dependency account must assume that the German and Hindi WC have radically different analyses – an assumption that Müller (1997) and Stechow and Sternefeld (1988) indeed make, but which faces the problem that Hindi kyaa and Marathi kai apparently differ with respect to (60) only. Consequently, if (60) matters so much, Hindi and Marathi WC would require completely different analyses.

As Mahajan (1996, 2000) points out, the marker for yes/no questions in Hindi is kyaa itself (but the same is true of Kashmiri k’a: cf. also Wali and Koul 1997), so that yes/no questions possibly involve an Xmax-operator in [Spec, CP] in Hindi. In this sense, W6 could be reformulated as W6* in a much stronger form. Whether this is convincing depends on what analysis one can give to Kashmiri k’a and how data such as (61) should be analyzed.
WC is possible only with questions that involve a +wh-specifier.

An indirect-dependency account of the type proposed in Mahajan (1996), Fanselow and Mahajan (1996, 2000), and Horvath (1997) can exclude (60a) easily. Recall that these theories assume that the WP is a sentential expletive which is replaced by its CP associate at LF. The equivalence of the WC and a corresponding long-movement construction is guaranteed by the assumption that an XP in the specifier position of Σ may take scope over whatever Σ c-commands at LF. A wh-phrase filling the specifier position of a CP which is itself the specifier of the matrix clause can therefore take scope over this matrix clause. If a wh-element is not the specifier in a CP, its scope will not be extended. The parameterization with respect to W6 can then be expressed in terms of the specifier status of the Q-morpheme in yes/no questions (as Mahajan 1996 suggests), or by allowing scope extension for specifiers and heads in certain languages.

In Dayal's version of the indirect-dependency account it is less obvious what could be responsible for the ungrammaticality of (60a, c, d). After all, the semantic function of restricting the domain of quantification of the WP-quantifier (which is central to her theory) could be fulfilled by a yes/no question as well. Thus, one option is again the assumption that while Dayal's theory is correct for Hindi, it does not cover the German WC, which needs a fairly different analysis then, and again one needs to be aware of the fact that this forces one to assume different analyses for Hindi and Marathi, too. Pointing to the (alleged) existence of dialects of German for which (60a) or versions of it are claimed to be fine (see Brandner 1996, Staudacher 2000, and Fanselow and Mahajan 2000 for an assessment) is just half the story, because the need to account for the more restrictive dialects does not disappear because of this. Note that yes/no questions have a distribution different from the one of complement questions. There are a number of verbs which accept only the latter as complements, as (63) illustrates. Thus, there is a semantic difference between yes/no and constituent questions after all. Whether or not the relevant factor could be used to account for W6 or W6* has not been thoroughly considered in the literature so far.

subsection.heading: 2.2.6 Infinitives
subsection.p: In a WC, the real wh-phrase must occupy [Spec, CP] if the language does not allow simple in situ wh-questions (see (64–65)). The CP related to the WP must be a legal constituent question (but see below). Generalization W7 captures the fact that WC does not arise with infinitives in German, as (66) illustrates, because there are no wh-infinitives, and it also captures the the fact that (67a) is, in contrast, possible in Iraqi Arabic because (67b) is also fine – if, to stress the point again, the construction is correctly analyzed as a WC. See section 2.3.2. for an exception to W7.

(64)
a. *Was

liebt?

‘Who do you think that Mary loves?’

‘Who did Sita think that Ravi saw?’

Generalization W7 is a straightforward consequence of indirect-dependency approaches and may seem to find rather easy explanations in the direct-dependency accounts, too. It is not clear, however, whether W7 is the crucial factor for the ban on infinitives in WC: Hungarian allows wh-infinitives (Horvath 1997; exx. (34–35)), yet no WC can be formed with infinitival complements, as (68b) shows. Thus, with the possible exception of Iraqi Arabic (67a) that would not be exceptional at all if it is not an instance of a WC, W8 seems to hold as well, without being reducible to W7, as Hungarian shows.

(68)
a. Kivel
akarsz beszélni? Hungarian
who-with you-want-IO to talk
b. *Mit
akarz kivel
beszélni?
what you-want who-with to talk
‘Who do you want to talk to?’
c. Nem tudok mit
mondani.
not I know what to say
‘I do not know what to say.’
WC do not show up with infinitival complements.

There is no account of the WC which implies W8 without further assumptions. Direct-dependency accounts might take recourse to the idea that infinitives have a CP specifier position in very restricted circumstances only (as in (63)), so that one of the key preconditions for the availability of a WC in the movement languages – namely, that the real wh-phrase appears in [Spec, CP] – cannot be met. For the wh-in-situ languages, it seems to hold that infinitives do not delimit the scope of a wh-phrase they contain, so that the insertion of a WP would be superfluous for, say, the scope-taking of a wh-phrase in a Hindi infinitive – recall we have already seen that kyaa insertion must have a semantic effect. Alternatively, one might say that infinitives have a [Spec, CP] position which is not ‘type-compatible’ with the [Spec, CP] position of a finite clause, so that they could not form part of the same chain. See also section 2.2 for a further attempt of an explanation.

Indirect-dependency approaches with a syntactic component (Mahajan, Horvath) might restrict the replacement of the wh-expletive by its clausal associate to finite CPs. There is a straightforward explanation for Generalization W8 in Dayal's system for Hindi. As discussed in Dayal (1996b), Hindi does not allow indirect-question readings for infinitivals. The analogue of You know what to do can only be an indirect question. This account cannot be carried over to Hungarian because of (68c) – but one might take recourse to syntactic constraints on ‘associate formation’ in this approach, too.

subsection.heading: 2.2.7 The complement status of the associate clause: extraction and binding
subsection.p: Horvath (1997) has observed that the CP hosting the real wh-phrase in a WC (the clausal associate of the WP) is transparent for extractions in Hungarian (69). The same holds for those dialects of German which tolerate topicalization out of wh-islands (70). Similar constructions are ungrammatical in Hindi. 7

(69)
Itt van az a színésznő [akinek nem emlékszem hogy Hungarian
here is that the actress who-Dat not I recall that
mit
kért János hogy kit
mutassunk be.
what asked John that who we-introduce Sub
‘Here is the actress for whom I do not remember who John asked that we should introduce to her.’

(70)
Den Josef weiss ich nicht
was
sie meint wie
wir überzeugen könnten.
the Joseph know I not what she means how we convince could
‘As for Josef, I do not know how she believes that we can convince him.’

Examples (69–70) not only show that the wh-island condition is not respected in the pertinent languages, they also suggest that the clause c headed by the real wh-phrase is a complement rather than an adjunct – would it be different, c should be opaque for movement, given that most theories of barriers and islands for movement imply that adjuncts cannot be extracted from. Direct-dependency accounts immediately predict this behavior – the wh-island condition (Ross 1986) is the only constraining factor that could be relevant.

The indirect-dependency approaches face greater problems – if the WP is a clausal expletive and the wh-clause its associate, it is by no means necessary that the latter occupies a complement position. If the WP is placed into the specifier position of some object agreement phrase (or the specifier position of some verbal projection), as Mahajan (1996) and Horvath (1997) assume, then the complement position of VP can still host the clause linked to the WP. One needs to keep in mind, however, that object clauses linked to a non-wh CP-expletive are islands for movement, as has been observed by Bennis (1986) and others. Therefore, indirect-dependency approaches must subscribe to the view that wh- and non-wh-expletives have different effects on the transparency of their associates for movement.

(71)
Den Fritz glaube ich (*es) nicht dass sie liebt.
the-Acc Fritz believe I it not that she loves
‘I do not believe that she loves Fritz.’

Horvath (1997) takes the grammaticality of (69) to be one out of three major arguments against Dayal's view of the WC. If the WP is the real argument (as Dayal claims), and the wh-introduced clause a structural adjunct, the latter should not be transparent for extraction. Horvath's argument is convincing, but only to the extent that transparency for movement must be defined in structural terms. The associate is semantically linked to the WP so that it may have argument status in the syntax quite independent of its position, as argued originally by Herburger (1994). Note also that clauses that appear in ‘extraposed’ positions are structural adjuncts (they are adjoined to VP or IP), without being necessarily opaque for movement; see German (72). If the complement clause is base-generated in a preverbal position, and if its postverbal surface position comes about by adjunction to, say, the right periphery of VP or CP, then wh-extraction of wen seems to have left a structural adjunct that is a thematic complement.

(72)
Wen hast du gedacht dass Irina liebt.
who have you thought that Irina loves

Fanselow and Mahajan (1996) and Horvath (1997) claim that (73–75) constitute arguments for a complement status of the CP-associate of the WP: a pronoun sitting in the clause introduced by the wh-question can be bound by a quantifier in the matrix clause.

subsection.heading: 2.2.8 The status of the CP-associate: Case and subjecthood
subsection.p: On the whole, Generalization W9 appears to be fulfilled, as (76) illustrates for Hindi and for German. For Hindi, this may be related to the fact that kyaa must normally appear in an immediately preverbal position (as (77) shows). It competes with the sentential expletive yah for the same position, as Dayal and Mahajan observe.
WC is incompatible with the presence of a sentential expletive in an object position.

(76)
a. *Siitaa-ne yah
kyaa
socaa ki ravii-ne kis-ko
dekhaa? Hindi
Sita it what thought that Ravi who saw
b. *Was
glaubte Sita es wen
Ravi sah?
what believed Sita it who Ravi saw
‘Who did Sita think that Ravi saw?’

(77)
Siitaa-ne
kyaa
(*abhii) socaa ki ravii-ne kis-ko
dekhaa?
Sita what just now thought that Ravi who saw
‘Who did Sita think that Ravi saw?’

Generalization W9 is generally predicted by indirect-dependency accounts, since they assume that the WP is generated/merged in the object position, or a specifier position linked to object agreement, which cannot be filled twice. In a direct-dependency account, W9 must be analyzed as a reflection of the greater island sensitity of chain formation in a WC as compared to standard wh-movement (see, e.g., Müller (1997)) – after all, clausal associates of sentential expletives are islands for movement (recall ex. (71)), see Bennis (1986). Thus, (76) might be ungrammatical because no A-bar-chain can be built up that leaves the embedded clause, which is an island. This strong island sensitivity is a clear characteristic of German WC, but the situation is less clear in Hindi and Hungarian, so that recourse to island sensitivity may be justified for German, but perhaps not in general.

It has been claimed that the WC is restricted to object clauses in German (see, e.g., McDaniel 1989, where the same claim is made concerning Romani), i.e., that it is incompatible with clauses in (derived) subject positions, which would be surprising because neither Hindi (Mahajan 1996) nor Hungarian (see Horvath 1997 and (78)) share this property. Note that (78) also indicates that the formation of WC is less restrictive than overt movement in Hungarian.

(78)
a. Mi
zavarta Marit hogy kinek
telefonáltál? Hungarian
what-Nom disturbed Mary-Acc that who-Dat you-phoned
b. ?*Kinek
zavarta Marit hogy telefonáltál?
who-Dat disturbed Mary-acc that you-phoned
‘With whom did it disturb Mary that you have telephoned?’

The claim that German disallows a WC for (derived) subject clauses (that is widespread in the literature) is based on examples such as (79), which confound derived subjecthood and factivity, another factor restricting the WC in German, but not in other languages. When one tests non-factive subject clauses as in (80) (see Fanselow and Mahajan 2000), the results are grammatical.

(79)
*Was
ärgert es dich wen
sie liebt?

‘Who does it annoy you that she loves?’

(80)
Es ist egal
was
in der Zeitung steht wen
sie liebt.
it is equal what in the newspaper stands who she love
‘It does not matter who the newspapers say she loves.’

Thus, we can conclude that the WC is possible – in principle – with both object and (derived) subject clauses in Hindi and German (the CP would therefore always originate in object position). Hungarian is even less restricted, as Horvath (1997) observes: the WC is possible with adverbial clauses, although these are (just like subject clauses) barriers for syntactic movement:

(81)
a. Miert
vagy dühös mert kivel
találkoztál? Hungarian
why you-are angry because who-with you had met
b. *Kivel
vagy dühös mert találkoztál?
who-with you-are angry because you had met
‘Lit.: ‘With whom are you angry because you had met.’

In an indirect-dependency account, a simple explanation suggests itself for the restrictions on German and Hindi WCs in constrast to Hungarian: it is related to the Case born by the WP. In Hindi, CPs show up in positions only that would bear absolutive (= structural) case. In German, CPs may show up in positions only that would be assigned nominative (= structural) or accusative (= structural) Case (if filled by an NP), as Fanselow and Felix (1987) have argued, but they cannot appear in positions that receive non-structural, lexical Case. These generalizations can be derived from the Case Resistance Principle of Stowell (1981): CPs must not be assigned Case. If the assignment of structural Case is always optional, CPs may replace NPs in the corresponding positions. If the assignment of non-structural Case is mandatory, the Case Resistance Principle prevents CPs from appearing there.

Suppose that sentential expletives are like any other sentential category in being restricted to potentially Case-free positions. Then we can understand why Hindi and German WC are confined to structural Case positions. Stepanov (2001: 178) explains the restricted nature of the Russian WC in these terms as well: jak ‘how’ simply has to be Case-less. On the other hand, if a sentential pro-form happens to be compatible with lexical Case, the WC should not be restricted to structural Case positions. Consider (82) in this respect. German was is normally replaced by wo (lit. ‘where’) in the complement position of PPs. The literature on German tends to consider WCs ungrammatical when the WP would be a complement in a PP, independent of whether wo is extracted from PP (82a) or pied-pipes the preposition (82b) (e.g., Fanselow and Mahajan 2000), but Klepp (2001) points out that some speakers accept such examples. The pertinent variation among speakers of German can easily be described in terms of lexical properties of the WP (can it receive oblique Case?).

(82)
a. #Wo
hast du nicht mit gerechnet wem Irina schrieb?
where have you not with reckoned who Irina wrote
b. #Womit hast du nicht
gerechnet wem Irina schrieb?
‘Who have you not taken it into consideration that Irina wrote to?’

For Hungarian, one would assume that CP pro-forms may in general show up in all Case positions – there are no relevant restrictions on the Case the CP receives. If the restrictions on WC we focus on here are due to Case constraints, the greater degree of freedom for WC in Hungarian becomes understandable. Notice in particular that, as (83) corroborates, the Case expressed by the WP in Hungarian is identical with the Case that would be assigned to the corresponding propositional argument. This Case pattern falls out nicely in the indirect-dependency account, as Horvath (1997) stresses, because the WP is linked to the propositional complement rather than to the wh-phrase of this complement in these approaches.

(83)
Mire
számítasz hogy melyik
fiúval
fog Mari beszélni? Hungarian
what-All you count that which boy-with will Mary speak
‘With which boy do you rely on it that Mary will speak?’

For direct-dependency accounts, Hungarian data such as (81) are problematic to a certain extent. That WC formation is possible for subject and object clauses in German and Hindi is unspectacular since subject clauses are transparent for movement in these languages, too, so that one should expect other kinds of chain formation like scope marking in a WC to behave similarly. Quite in line with that, both WCs and overt long movement are impossible for adjunct clauses in German and Hindi. Arguably, then, the core island restrictions on WC formation (= scope marking) and long movement are identical. For Hungarian, however, one would have to assume that chain formation by scope marking is more liberal than chain formation by movement (see also next section). However, it is by no means obvious why the ‘scope marker’ does not bear the case of the wh-phrase it is claimed to mark the scope of in Hungarian – but rather the case of the CP that dominates that wh-phrases. Technical solutions are certainly possible, but the data is expected in a strict sense in the indirect-dependency theory only.

subsection.heading: 2.2.9 Negative-island effects
subsection.p: In Hindi (84a), German (84b), Passamaquoddy (Brüning 2001), and other languages, the WP cannot appear in a negative clause or when there is a negative quantifier in the clause. It is not likely, however, that this behavior characterizes a general property of WCs, because the WC is compatible with negation in Hungarian, as (84c) shows, and apparently marginally so in Croatian (D. Ćavar, p.c.). Example (84d) illustrates again that the WC is more flexible than movement in Hungarian, which does show the negative-island effect.

Thus, a negation must not c-command a wh-phrase in situ (85), it must not intervene in a split construction (86), and it must not show up in the so-called copy construction (87) of German (see Fanselow and Ćavar 2000 for a detailed analysis).

(87)

sie liebt?

‘Who do you think that she loves?’
c. *Wen

sie liebt?
