‘Who don't you think that she loves?’

Example (85) suggests that a negative element cannot intervene between a wh-phrase and its scope position in German – for direct-dependency approaches, this assumption suffices to rule out (84b), and the same logic may also be applied in the Mahajan–Horvath–Fanselow approach. Sentence (86) shows that negation cannot intervene between a quantificational element and it restrictor either – this is sufficient for ruling out (84b) in the Dayal-approach. Thus, the negation data (and related facts involving universal quantifiers) are expected in all theories of the WC. Therefore, the data cannot be used to argue for a quasi-parenthetical status of the WC (Reis 1996), nor to establish that there is a deep link between the WC and, e.g., the copy construction (Höhle 1996; Fanselow and Mahajan 1996, 2000). It may be added, however, that structures that are closer to (84a, b) than (84c) are unacceptable in Hungarian as well, as (88) illustrates. ‘Negative-island violations’ are fine in Hungarian only with verbs that presuppose a pre-existing set of propositions (such as admit, reveal, deny, notice, permit) – they are ungrammatical with other matrix verbs (such as think, say, feel). The real difference between, on one hand, German and Hindi, and on the other hand, Hungarian, thus lies in the fact that structures such as (84a, b) fail to improve when the former group of matrix verbs is used. What we observe in (88) is a pragmatically caused negative island effect in the sense of Kuno and Takami (1997); see Horvath (1997) for a detailed analysis,

beszélt Mari? Hungarian

subsection.heading: 2.2.10 Verb-class effects
subsection.p: In German, factive verbs do not allow WC (89). The same holds for Kashmiri (Wali and Koul 1997: 19).

(89)

bedauerte Fritz wen
sie liebt?

‘Who did Fritz regret that she loves?’

While direct-dependency approaches explain this restriction in terms of the island status of the complements of factive verbs, indirect-dependency theories have no simple explanation for the ungrammaticality of (89) – not too bad a property, perhaps, since neither Hindi nor Hungarian (90) share the restrictiveness of German and Kashmiri. Sentence (91b) illustrates again that Hungarian overt adjunct movement is in line with the expectation that factive islands affect extraction, so that the grammaticality of (90) is a problem for at least those versions of the direct-dependency approach that assume that chain formation in WC follows the laws of adjunct extraction.

(90)
Mit
felejtett el Mari hogy kivel
beszélt már? Hungarian
what forgot Mary that with whom she-spoke already
‘With whom did Mary forget that she had already spoken?’

(91)
a. Mit
sajnálsz hogy hogy
viszelkedtek a gyerekek? Hungarian

b. *Hogy
sajnálod hogy
viszelkedtek a gyerekek?
what you regret that
they-behaved the children
‘In what manner do you regret that the children behaved?’

Likewise, it has already been observed by McDaniel (1989) that certain volitional predicates in German are incompatible with the WC. This property is shared by the copy construction, but not by long movement. This further restriction is, however, apparently not obeyed in Hindi or in Hungarian. Likewise, Romani ‘tense dependent’ clauses enter WCs.

(92)
a. Wen
möchtest du dass sie liebt?
who want you that she loves
b. *Wen
möchtest du wen
sie liebt?
c. *Was
möchtest du wen
sie liebt?
‘Who do you want that she loves?’
d. Wen
hoffst du dass sie liebt?
e. *Wen
hoffst du wen
sie liebt?
f. *Was
hoffst du wen
sie liebt?
‘Who do you hope that she loves?’

Fanselow and Mahajan (1996, 2000) propose an account for this data in which the additional island effects are related to the fact that the copy construction and the WC lack an overt complementizer in the complement clause, in contrast to long movement constellations. McDaniel (1989) suggests that the complements of volitional predicates are semantically close to infinitivals, so that the ban on (92c, f) can be related to the poorly understood generalization W8 which excludes WCs with infinitival complements. It is hard to see, however, why the copy construction should obey the anti-infinitive restriction. One might also suspect that volitional predicates involve or are (hidden) modal operators after all, so that what we see in (92) is simply an intervention effect of the sort discussed in section 2.2.9. This seems tenable as long as the question of whether volitional predicates trigger intervention effects is subject to parameterization.

Reis (1996) observes that one further construction, so-called extractions from verb-second complements (see, e.g., Grewendorf 1988) turns out to to share the constraints discussed above with WC and CC. In Fanselow and Mahajan's (1996, 2000) view, (93) just illustrates the importance of having an overt complementizer for not being subject to various additional constraints. This is not convincing, however, because the set of predicates that tolerate extractions from verb-second complements is more or less identical with the set of predicates that tolerates verb-second complements – and furthermore, Vikner (1995) observes that the set of predicates that tolerates verb-second complements in German is roughly identical to the set of predicates that takes verb-second complements introduced by a complementizer in the Scandinavian languages. 8 Therefore, the absence of the complementizer in the relevant complements is a spurious side-effect in German. The intervention approach is able to account for the facts in (93) in an indirect fashion: if it is true that the grammaticality of verb-second complements is linked to the availability of a matrix-like assertive component located in the complement clause (say, in terms of the feature determination of tense and mood), and if this component must be linked to the matrix clause Comp, then negative, volitional, and factive predicates may trigger intervention effects. Now for the relation between the two Comp/Infl nodes.

(93)
a. Wen
glaubt sie liebt er?
who believes she loves he
‘Who does she believe that he loves?’
b. *Wen
glaubt keiner liebt er? negative islands
who believes nobody loves he
‘Who does nobody believe that he loves?’
c. *Wen
bedauert sie liebt er? factive islands
who regrets she loves he
‘Who does she regret that he loves?’
d. *Wen

who wishes she loves he
‘Who does she wish that he loves?’

Such an account would not be accepted by Reis (1996). She brings yet another array of facts into the discussion of WC and points out that certain types of parentheticals behave like the WC. The particular constraints on German WC – namely, negative islands and factive and volitional verbs – are respected by parentheticals of the types illustrated in (94) as well.

(94)
a. Wen
liebt sie, was glaubst du?
who loves she, what think you?
a′. Wen
-was glaubst du- liebt sie?
‘What do you think – who does she love?’
b. *Wen
liebt sie, was glaubst du nicht?
who loves she, what think you not
b′. *Wen
-was glaubst du nicht- liebt sie?
‘What don't you think – who does she love?’
c. *Wen
liebt sie, was bedauerst du?
who loves she, what regret you?
c′. *Wen
-was bedauerst du- liebt sie?
‘What do you think – who does she love?’
d. *Wen
liebt sie, was wünsct du?
who loves she, what wish you?
d′. *Wen
-was bedauerst du- liebt sie?
‘What do you think – who does she love?’

For Reis (1996), this apparent correlation between WC, parentheticals, and verb-second complements can be explained only if we attribute a parenthetical status to both the WC and (extractions from) verb-second complements. This solution is faced with the same problem as the Fanselow and Mahajan account: It has hard to see what a parenthetical analysis could be of, e.g., Danish verb-second clauses introduced by an overt complementizer; see (95).

(95)
Watson påstod at disse penge havde Moriarty stjålet. Danish
Watson claimed that this money had Moriarty stolen
‘Watson claimed that Moriarty had stolen this money.’

subsection.heading: 2.2.11 Agreement
subsection.p: Passamaquoddy, as described in chapter 4 of Bruening (2001), allows interesting insights into the syntax of WC. Overt movement (focus movement, relative clauses, wh-questions) triggers participle agreement on the verb. Long-distance questions can trigger participle agreement all along the path of movement; the same holds for long-distance relativization and long-distance focalization, see (96) (= Bruening's (72a)), in which the agreement markers appear in boldface.

(96)
Wen-ihi piluwitaham-oc-ihi
Piyel kisi-komutonom-ac-ihi? Passamaquoddy
who-ObvP suspect-2Conj-PartObvP Piyel Perf-rob-3Conj-PartObvP
‘Who all do you suspect that Piyel robbed?’

Focus-movement constructions and internally headed relative clauses show that covert A-bar movement can trigger participle agreement on all verbs along the movement path as well. This is illustrated in (27), repeated here as (97).

(97)
Tehpu kesiciy-uk-il
wisukiluwohehtw-ac-il
Maliw-ol. Passamaquoddy
only I know he-made-angry Mary-Obv
In the WC, however, it is absolutely impossible for agreement to appear above the position of the contentful wh-phrase, as a comparison of the data in (98) reveals (= Bruening's (119)).

(98)
a. Keqsey cel elitahasi-t wen-il
nemiy-ac-il? Passamaquoddy
what even IC.think-3Conj who-Obv IC.see-3Conj-PartObv
b. *Keqsey cel elitahasi-c-il
wen-il
nemiy-ac-il?
what even IC.think-3Conj-PartObv who-Obv IC.see-3Conj-PartObv
‘Who did he think he saw?’

Bruening concludes that the WC in Passamaquoddy cannot involve covert movement of the contentful wh-phrase – if it did, (98b) should be grammatical. The facts of Passamaquoddy suggest that the direct-dependency account is not correct for at least some languages with a WC.

subsection.heading: 2.3 Conclusions
subsection.p: All theoretical approaches introduced here make reference only to concepts that are independently motivated – there are clear cases of scope marking for wh-phrases, there are sentential expletive-associate pairs, there are clear cases of a specifier taking wider scope than its immediate c-command domain, etc. A decision among the rivaling theories of the WC, therefore cannot be taken on purely theoretical grounds.

subsection.heading: 2.3.1 A historical dimension?
subsection.p: The picture that emerges from the above discussion is not necessarily a clear-cut one. One or the other generalization may favor a particular type of analysis (the direct-dependency approach fares better, e.g., with respect to W3 and W6 and with immobility facts; the indirect-dependency approach fares better with W1, W9, the Hungarian Case facts, and in particular with agreement in Passamaquoddy), but with the few exceptions discussed earlier, all theories are technically capable of capturing the relevant data. If one wants to assess the evidence, then, a number of decisions have to be made, the first one concerning the plausibility of finding a syntactic analysis that is applicable to all instances of the WC. The opposing view, endorsed by Dayal (1996a, 1996b) and Reis (1996), would be that there is a spectrum of different analyses for constructions that are superficially similar but represent different stages in a historical development from a bi-clausal entity such as (99) to a scope-marking construction as in Japanese (100). These options might be ordered as indicated in Table 47.1. There seems to be a sharp difference between A and B in Table 47.1, and also between D and E, because we saw that Iraqi Arabic sh/sheno is exceptional in at least two respects; the WP is not really homophononous with ‘what’ or ‘how’, and the construction fails to observe a number of generalizations (W2, W3, W4, W7) that otherwise hold for the WC. It thus seems fair to conclude that the status as a WC may be more part of the history than of the current analysis of Iraqi Arabic sh/sheno.
(99) What do you think: will she invite him?

(100)
John-ga dare-o butta ka sirinai Japanese
John-Nom who-Acc what Q know-not
‘Who did you give that book?’

If this assessment is correct, one has to establish whether there is compelling evidence to allow for different analyses for the WC in Hindi (and other Indian languages), Hungarian, and German (and other Germanic languages). The key differences in descriptive terms have been identified above: the WC is not restricted to constituent questions in Hindi, and there is a rich system of overt case variation of the WP in Hungarian. According to the discussion above, however, these differences are not sufficient to motivate radical syntactic differences among the three language types in question.

subsection.heading: 2.3.2 Clear arguments?
subsection.p: There seems to be some consensus that the Hindi WC should be analysed in terms of an indirect-dependency approach since it may seem unlikely that a scope marker for wh-elements appears in a preverbal position rather than in [Spec, CP]. Furthermore, as we have seen earlier, kyaa and the sentential expletive are incompatible with each other (see section 2.2.8), presumably because they compete for the same position, a strictly preverbal one. Note, however, that it is not uncommon that wh-scope markers appear on the verb. Furthermore, the wh-phrase can be moved into the clause it takes scope over in Hindi, as (101) shows. This “wh-scrambling” operation (Mahajan 1990) may indeed place the wh-phrase into the specifier position of a functional projection (a Focus phrase, e.g.?) – a picture that may be blurred in Hindi by extensive further options for the scrambling of other XPs – and a view that would make Hindi resemble Hungarian in the relevant respects quite strongly. Thus, claims that the Hindi WC could not possibly be analyzed as a scope-marking construction are not compelling.

(101)
Raam-ne kyaa
socaa ki ravi-ne kyaa
kahaa ki kOn sa aadmii
aayaa thaa? Hindi
Raam-erg WHAT thinks that Ravi-Erg WHAT said that which man came
Raam-ne kyaa socaa ki kOn sa aadmii ravi-ne kahaa ki aayaa thaa?
Raam-ne
kOn sa aadmii socaa ki ravi-ne kahaa ki aayaa thaa?

The situation in Hungarian may be different in this respect – Hungarian data may be the clearest one favoring a particular approach to WC. On the one hand, the Case data discussed in section 2.2.8 strongly argue in favor of indirect-dependency approaches. On the other hand, the data discussed in 2.2.7 show that the CP hosting the real wh-phrase is a complement. According to Horvath (1997) this implies that the WP must be an expletive. As we saw above, this conclusion presupposes a purely structural notion of argument/complement status.

Horvath (1997) brings forward two further arguments that she believes are incompatible with Dayal's version of the indirect-dependency theory. She points points out that (102a), but not (102b), can be answered by ‘nothing’ or ‘nothing of interest’, a contrast that she claims is not easy to account for if the function of the was in the two examples is essentially the same, as Dayal (1996a, 1996b) claims. Whether felicity conditions for question–answer pairs decide between syntactic analysis is not fully clear, though. However, as Dayal (2000) points out, questions such as which student came? also cannot be answered by nobody. The felicity of answers to questions depends on the presuppostions linked to specific forms of question, and the contrast in (102) might be captured in these terms.

(102)
a. Was
glaubt Maria?
b. Was
glaubt Maria wie
wir das Problem lösen können?
what believes Mary how we the problem solve can
The argument involving (103) may be stronger. In a Hungarian WC, the wh-phrase moved upwards may be included in a yes/no question:

(103)
Mit
kérdeztek hogy kivel
találkozutam-e? Hungarian
what asked-they that who-with I-met-Q-Prt
‘With whom did they ask whether I had met?’

According to Horvath (1997), such structures are difficult to capture in Dayal-style accounts. Recall that according to Dayal (1996a, 1996b), mit would simply be a wh-quantifier ‘what’ that is restricted by the meaning of its associate, which itself must be a semantically legitimate question. It may be unclear what semantic object a combination of a yes/no question and a constituent question is – such entities do not exist outside WC. However, a sketch of how such data (and possible Hindi counterparts) might be handled even if mit is an argumental wh-phrase can be found in Dayal (2000: 188).

It seems fair to conclude, then, that a number of empirical facts from different languages favor an indirect-dependency account for the WC. The version of the indirect-dependency approach proposed by Dayal (1994, 1996a, 1996b, 2000) has the conceptual advantage that the real wh-phrase moves up to its scope position (in the narrow sense) in the syntax, so that the WC does not involve partial wh-movement from a grammatical point of view. Consequently, the theoretical problems discussed in 1.3. simply would not arise.

subsection.heading: 2.3.3 A possible compromise?
subsection.p: It might be added that the difference between direct dependency approaches and indirect ones of the sort proposed by Horvath, Mahajan, and Fanselow turns out to be smaller than it may seem at first glance. There is some evidence suggesting that long wh-movement has to pass through a specifier position linked to the VP:

li.p: in Palauan (Georgopoulos 1991b; Watanabe 1996) and many other languages, the verb agrees with a wh-phrase that has passed the verb on its way to the scope position (e.g., with respect to number, gender, or definitiveness)
in Quechua (Lefebvre and Muysken 1982) and many other languages, a wh-phrase from a lower clause may pick up a Case assigned by the matrix verb.

in Dutch 9 and some varieties of German (Fanselow and Ćavar 2000), phonetic material of a wh-phrase having undergone long movement may be stranded 10 in the context of wh-movement in the preverbal position of the matrix clause.

subsection.p: In Chomsky (1986a) it was argued that the wh-phrase adjoins to VP on its way up, an idea that has been revived in Chomsky (2000), the difference being that the wh-phrase now moves to a specifier position of vP/AgrO. Consider now the constellation in (104), in which a wh-phrase taking scope over CP* has been moved to the specifier position of a lower CP. As the next step, the wh-phrase might be moved to [Spec, AgrO], i.e., to the position Δ, or an expletive E might be inserted into Δ. In the latter case, this expletive E should agree with the object of the verb – i.e., it should have a clausal status, bear the case of the clausal complement, etc., but it should also be able to agree with the specifier of CP with respect to the wh-feature – because (unlike the specifier's case) this is a feature of the CP*s specifier the verb could subcategorize for (see Chomsky 1986a). Such a line of reasoning might bring the two approaches to WC fairly close to each other, but that point has not been investigated thoroughly so far (see Fanselow and Mahajan 2000 for some discussion).
(104) [CP* . . . [AgrO-Phrase Δ [AgrO [[VP V [CP wh-phrase COMP′]]]] . . . ]

subsection.heading: 3.1 Simple partial movement
subsection.p: In contrast to the considerable amount of work concerned with the WC, few studies only have dealt with simple partial movement as exemplified again in (105) for Bahasa Indonesia (Saddy 1991). A wh-phrase may either stay in situ, or move up to some position which is not higher than its LF scope (105a–c). Similar constructions are well-formed in Singaporean Malay (Cole and Hermon 1998b), Kikuyu (Sabel 2000), Buli (Ferreira and Ko 2000), Slave (as illustrated in (6b), see Rice 1989, Basilico 1998) and other Athabascan languages (Western Apache, Potter 1997; Babine-Witsuwit’en, Denham 2000), and in Ancash Quechua (Cole 1982b).

(105)
a. Siapa
yang Bill tahu
Tom cintai? Bahasa Indonesia
who
foc
Bill knows
Tom loves
b.
Bill tahu siapa
yang Tom cintai?
who
foc
c.
Bill tahu
Tom men-cintai siapa?
loves who
‘Who does Bill know that Tom loves?’
We argued earlier for the generalizations S1 and S2, to which we will return to below.
If a language tolerates SPM, it also tolerates wh-elements in situ and allows full wh-movement.
If a construction is grammatical with SPM, it can also be constructed with a wh-phrase in situ.

subsection.heading: 3.1.1 The relation to focus movement
subsection.p: Note that the fronting of siapa in (105a, b) is accompanied by the insertion of the particle yang, and the deletion of particles such as men (105c) marking transitivity. The marker yang may be omitted in certain varieties of Malay (Cole and Hermon 1998b). In Kikuyu, the wh-phrase is prefixed by a focus particle when it has undergone partial or complete wh-movement, as (106) shows.

(106)
a. Kama.ú a-ón-’ìrϵ o? Kikuyu
Kamau SP-see-T who
‘Who did Kamau see?’
b. Nóo
ó-&ggr;w-eciìri-a [Ngo&ggr;e a-ú&ggr;-írϵ áte o-on-írϵ Kaanakϵ]?
FP-who you-think N. said that saw Kanake
‘Who do you think Ngo&ggr;e said that Kaanake saw?’
c. Ó-&ggr;w-eciìri-á [nóo
Ngo&ggr;e a-ú&ggr; -írϵ áte o-on-írϵ Kaanakϵ?
d. Ó-&ggr;w-eciìri-á Ngo&ggr;e a-ú&ggr;-írϵ nóo
ate o-on-írϵ Kaanakϵ?

If Cheng (1997) and Saddy (1991) correctly analyze Bahasa Indonesia yang as a focus marker (107), it is tempting to analyze (105b) as a instance of movement to an intermediate focus position, instead of partial wh-movement. Note that when there is full wh-movement (as in 105a), yang is inserted as well. It would thus be likely that the full movement of siapa goes to the specifier of a focus phrase as well, and there is no evidence that this position is not also the one siapa occupies at LF. Thus, there is no principled reason for not considering what we see in (105) and (106) as instances of (partial) wh-movement (since wh-phrases move to focus positions in many other languages as well). According to Saddy (1991) the absence of parasitic gaps with partial or full wh-movement (in line with what holds for focus movement, and in contrast to topicalization) and the absence of weak crossover effects argue against an analysis of the fronting in (105) in terms of wh-movement. But there are no principled grounds that would require that wh-movement always licenses parasitic gaps, and a lot of languages do not show weak crossover effects with wh-movement. So this argument is not compelling.

(107)
Buku-buku yang saya cium.
books Foc I love

In contrast, the omissibility of yang in Singaporean Malay (see Cole and Hermon 1998b) need not be seen as a reason against analyzing relevant wh-frontings as being due to focus movement (rather than wh-movement), but the observation also certainly does not strengthen Saddy's position. Similarly, the presence of a focus particle on moved wh-words in Kikuyu is compatible with the idea that (partial) wh-movement is not necessarily wh-movement in a strict sense in this language. In Slave (Rice 1989: 1162, 1165), however, the marker ri for focus may (108) but need not (109) be present with wh-elements in situ and wh-elements that have undergone partial movement. Basilico (1998) claims it is therefore hard to maintain that the partial movement of question phrases is always focus movement in Slave – but the contrary does not follow from the facts either.

(108)
a. Raymond Jane judeni
ri yili kodisho? Slave
Raymond Jane where foc 3-is 3-knows
b. Raymond judeni
ri Jane yili kodishi
‘Where does Raymond know Jane to be?’

(109)
a. John seya judeni
ráwozée yudeli? Slave
John my son where 3-pot-hunt 3-want-4
b. John judeni
seya ráwozée yudeli?
‘Where does John want my son to hunt?’

In Babine-Witsuwit’en (Denham 2000) SPM and focus movement co-exist as well. In contrast to focus movement, no focus marker seems to appear on the wh-phrases that have undergone partial or complete wh-movement. According to Denham, wh-movement is strictly optional in this language.

To sum up, whether or not SPM can always be interpreted as an instance of focus movement is still an open question (see Cole and Hermon 1998b and Sabel 2000 for opposing views). Likewise, it is not clear whether going for the focus movement option instead of ‘wh-movement’ really makes a difference. An argument in favor of the position that the choice matters might be that focus movement does not serve the need of checking and/or licensing the wh-feature of the questions Comp. Rather, it serves the need of making the focal nature of wh-phrases explicit. For the former need, only one position is relevant (so that one might wonder why a phrases moves at all if it does not reach that position), for the latter requirement, any focus position available in the sentence will do. In any event, some explanation linking SPM to focus movement is called for, because – at least for the small sample of languages that has been investigated so far – generalization S3 appears to hold.
If a language allows SPM, wh-phrases can move to focus positions and can bear focus markers in that language.
If S3 is crucial for SPM, it would be difficult to integrate German and Romani (8) (partial movement of the second wh-phrase in a multiple question) into an analysis of SPM.

subsection.heading: 3.1.2 Locality
subsection.p: One important observation of Saddy (1991) is that partially moved wh-phrases differ from wh-elements in situ with respect to island sensitivity, as (110) illustrates. The presence of a negative island does not prevent a wh-phrase in situ from taking wide scope in (110a), but as soon as it has undergone movement, ungrammaticality arises even though the overt movement did not cross the island. The pair (110c–d) shows the same for adjunct islands.

(110)
a. Tom tidak meng-harap Mary mem-beli apa?
Tom not expect Mary bought what
‘What did Tom not expect that Mary bought?’
b. *Tom tidak meng-harap apa yang Mary beli?
c. Kamu men-cemburui Bill karena saya berbicara dengan siapa?
you be jealous of Bill because I spoke with who
‘Who is such that you are jealous of Bill because I spoke with him?’
d. *Kamu men-cemburui Bill karena dengan siapa yang saya berbicara?
e. Kamu mem-cemburui Bill karena dengan Tom yang saya berbicara?
you be-jealous of Bill because with Tom Foc I spoke

Note that focus movement is possible within adjunct islands, as (110e) illustrates. Thus, if both types of attraction to a yang head have the same analysis, the non-well-formedness of (110b, d) must be due to the fact that the scope of apa/siapa goes beyond the island in the relevant examples.

The contrasts in (110a–d) suggest that wh-elements in situ and (partially) moved wh-phrases show different behavior in Bahasa Indonesia. Wh-elements in situ, it seems, are elements that need not undergo movement at all, not even in the covert component. They are bound unselectively by a wh-operator (see Tsai 1994a, among others). Therefore, no island effects can arise, and it is – in a sense – also expected that – according to Saddy – wh-phrases in situ always take wide scope: (111a) unambiguously asks for the (single) person that is loved by everybody, while (111b, c) show the scope ambiguity one is familiar with from corresponding English examples.

(111)
a. Setiap orang men-cintai siapa?
every person loves who
b. Siapa
yang setiap orang cintai?
who
foc
every person loves
c. Setiap orang tahu apa
yang Tom beli?
every person knows what Foc Tom bought

A further observation is in line with this assumption concerning wh-elements in situ. Example (112a) has only the indicated reading, while ambiguities arise (ceteris paribus) as soon as the wh-phrase is (partially) moved (112b).

(112)
a. Kamu meng-gira Jon men-ceritakan Mary tahu Tom mem-beli apa?
you think John mentioned Mary know Tom bought what
‘What do you think that John mentioned that Mary knows that Tom bought?’
b. Kamu gira Jon ceritakan Mary tahu apa yang Tom beli?
‘what do you think that John mentioned that Mary knows that Tom bought?’
‘You think that John mentioned what Mary knows that Tom bought?’
‘You think that John mentioned that Mary knows what Tom bought?’

The clear differences Saddy observes in Bahasa Indonesia for wh-phrases in situ and for partially and fully wh-moved phrases are not visible in Singaporean Malay according to Cole and Hermon (1998b). Nevertheless, the Malay languages share what we saw in (110), i.e., they support S4.
A wh-phrase that has undergone (partial) wh-movement must not be separated from its scope position by an island for movement.

The wh-in-situ strategy is less restrictive than overt movement in Slave (Basilico 1998), as (113) shows: the complements of so-called ‘indirect discourse verbs’ are barriers for overt movement, but wh-in-situ is licensed (113b). In the light of S4, it is surprising that (113c) involving partial movement is grammatical.

(113)
a. *?Ode
netá nimbáa enáih?á kenéhdzáh Slave
where your father tent 3-pitch 3-tried
‘Where did your father try to pitch the tent?’
b. Raymond Jane judeni ri yili kodisho
Raymond Jane where Foc 3-is 3-knows
c. Raymond [judeni ri Jane yili] kodisho
‘Where does Raymond know Jane to be?’ (Rice 1989; ex. 1875a, b)

Slave differs from the Malay dialects in a further respect; there are configurations in which partial movement is ruled out, while complete movement is not: complements of direct discourse verbs are transparent for movement, but disallow partial movement:

(114)
a. John beya judeni
ráwozée sudeli?
John my son where 3-Opt.hunt 3-wants-1
‘Where does John want my son to hunt?’
b. *John judeni beya ráwozée sudeli
c. Hodi
nurse egháuhndá néndi?
where nurse 1-Opt-see-2-Sg 3-told-2
‘Where did the nurse tell you she would see you?’

Basilico (1998) suggests that complements of direct-discourse verbs lack a [Spec, CP] node (so that (113b) could not possibly arise) – the fact that the difference between direct- and indirect-discourse complements is reminiscent of the one between finite and non-finite constructions in the European languages (at least with respect to transparency) would allow us to link (114b) to the impossibility of WC with infinitival complements.

Iraqi Arabic fulfills S4 as well, but only very indirectly. Tensed clauses are not islands for full overt movement, but they are for moved wh-phrases (and for wh-in-situ) in contrast to Bahasa Indonesia – one further crucial point concerning Iraqi Arabic is that wh-in-situ is not possible within syntactic islands (cf. 116).

(115)
a. Sheno
tsawwarit Mona Ali ishtara?
what thought Mona Ali bought
‘What did Mona think Ali bought?’
b. *Mona tsawwarit sheno Ali ishtara?
c. *Mona tsawwarit Ali ishtara sheno?

(116)
*Mona nasat li-meno
tinti sheno?
Mona forgot to whom to give what
‘What did Mona forget to whom to give?’

The observation S4 seems to imply that the partially moved wh-phrase builds up a link to its scope position that is subject to subjacency or similar constraints – but that this is part of a standard chain-building process is, perhaps, a premature conclusion. Recall that English clause-internal topicalization is subject to a comparable restriction (117), so the logic applied to S4 also forces a partial-movement account of English topicalization. Furthermore, the formation of verb-second structures is also banned within islands in the Germanic languages (see Vikner 1995) – keeping to the line of reasoning used earlier, we would need to assume some chain-formation process in, say, (118a–b) vs. (118c–d), too. Whether this is convincing or not cannot be decided now.

(117)
a. I believe that revenooers, he does not like.
b. *That revenooers he does not like is believed by everybody.

(118)
a. Ich glaube dass Peter ihn gesehen hat.
I think that Peter him seem has
b. Ich glaube Peter hat ihn gesehen.
I think Peter has him seen
‘I think (that) Peter has seen him.’
c. Dass Peter sie liebt überrascht mich.
that Peter her loves surprises me
d. *Peter liebt sie überrascht mich.
Peter loves her surprises me
‘It surprises me that Peter loves her.’

Although Passamaquoddy does not instantiate SPM in a strict sense, its PPM constructions shed an interesting light on the analysis of partial movement. Recall that Passamaquoddy has a WC, and that Bruening (2001) observed that there is no participle agreement on the verbs sitting between the ‘real’ wh-phrase and the WP. From this, he concluded that there is no covert movement of the real wh-phrase replacing the WP. In addition to the WC, Passamaquoddy also allows PPM. In line with what holds for the covert movement of focus operators, participle agreement is possible on any verb intervening between a wh-phrase that has undergone partial wh-movement, and the element tan that may be considered a scope marker. This suggests that a chain is built up between the partially moved wh-phrase and the scope position.

(119)
Tan elitahasi-yin-(ik) tan
kehsi-n
nemiy-oc-ik
apiqsehsuw-ok? Passamaquoddy
WH IC.think-2Conj-(Part3P) WH X.many-N IC.see-2Conj-Part3P rat-3P
‘How many rats do you think you saw?’

subsection.heading: 3.1.3 Analyses
subsection.p: SPM constructions can be and have been analyzed in various ways. Basilico (1998) and Cole and Hermon (1998b) analyse SPM as a subcase of the WC, the only difference being that the WP is unpronounced in Slave and the Malay languages. This allows us to relate the contrast between (113a), e.g., (no long movement) and (113c) (partial movement okay) to the situation of various German dialects that disallow long movement and use the WC instead. On its way to LF, the WP would be replaced by its associate in SPM as well. The various options for carrying this out were discussed earlier. The theoretical implications would be those of the WC.

Other approaches assume that the partially moved wh-phrase reaches its LF-scope position without the assistance of an overt scope marker. The position the wh-phrase occupies at LF would be a function of its wh-feature. Its overt position could be determined by the fact that it must be placed into a focus position, an analysis first argued for by Saddy (1991) and that would make SPM comparable, to, say, wh-scrambling or wh-imperatives: wh-phrases are displaced, but for reasons unrelated to the wh-feature they possess. SPM would thus fail to be an instance of PM in the strict sense. This might be an easier analysis than one in which there is true partial wh-movement in the strict sense.

New syntactic models such as the Minimalist Program (Chomsky 1995c) or Optimality Theory (e.g., Kager 1999) offer more flexibility. In particular, Fanselow and Ćavar (2000) take up ideas formulated, e.g., by Groat and O’Neal (1996) in their analysis of the SPM: movement is always an overt copying of a phrase from one position to another. The result of the copying operation is subject to an (economy based) set of principles that determined which of the copies so created will be spelled out eventually (see also Pesetsky 1997). Thus, for (105), one would assume that a chain with three occurences of siapa is formed first – as sketched in (120) – and that principles (possibly making reference to focus, an option not explicitly discussed in Fanselow and Ćavar 2000) determine which of these copies will be pronounced. In the easiest analysis of SPM, the relevant principle would not say a whole lot more than that exactly one copy has to be retained.
(120) Siapa yang Bill tahu siapa Tom cintai siapa?

One argument in favor of such a view may be found in the agreement facts illustrated in (119). Covert movement in the classical sense (following the spell-out of the whole construction, or of a phrase) may simply come too late for triggering the phonologically visible participle agreement. In the approach favored by Fanselow and Ćavar (2000), such agreement facts are expected. Cole and Hermon (1998b) argue that full overt movement theories involving separate spell-out positions cannot account for certain pecularities in the distribution of verbal prefixes in the Malay languages, but Fanselow and Ćavar (2000) claim they have developed the pertinent analysis.

The crucial differences between the analyses are therefore: (a) is a phonetically empty wh-expletive involved in the construction – which would make SPM and WC structurally identical – and if not: (b) does full movement to the scope position already happen in the overt component of grammar (as proposed by Fanselow and Ćavar 2000) or not (as in the focus movement accounts)? The only clear criterion we can apply seems to be generalization S3 that favors theories which link focus movement and partial movement to each other in one or the other way – but not necessarily so by making partial wh-movement an instance of focus movement.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Clausal pied-piping
subsection.p: Notice that there is a potential further analysis of SPM that has apparently not been proposed so far; we might link it to clausal pied-piping (CPP). The only difference between Basque (121) and SPM would be the fact that the pied-piping of the CP α the specifier of which is occupied by the wh-phrase happens at LF and not in overt syntax. As long as LF-movement can be phrasal (and ACD-constructions show it must be able to be so; see Pesetsky 2000 for a recent discussion) such an analysis will always be possible.

(121)
Nor
etorriko d-ela bihar esan diozu Mireni? Basque
who come Aux-that tomorrow said Aux to Mary
‘Who did you say to Mary t will come tomorrow?’
‘That who will come tomorrow have you said to Mary.’

The analysis of (121) seems much more obvious than the one of the constructions discussed earlier. There is a clear grammatical concept of pied-piping in the course of movement. In the spirit of Chomsky (1995c), options for pied-piping can be ordered as in (122), which are (partially) illustrated in (111). Note that in such a system the interesting question is not so much why (121) is possible at all, but, rather, why clausal pied-piping seems so rare. An answer might be sought in the idea that pied-piping is always a last-resort phenomenon and should be minimal (see, e.g., Chomsky 1995c), but a thorough discussion of pied-piping is clearly beyond the scope of this chapter.

Note, however, that CPP and WC stand in a close relation if the latter is analysed as involving a clausal expletive. Suppose S in (124) is the scope position for a wh-phrase moved to the specifier position of CP#. The wh-phrase might then move further up alone or it might pied-pipe CP#. Instead of moving CP#, an expletive (the WP) might be inserted, ending up in S, where it is finally replaced by CP# in an instance of LF clausal pied-piping.

Van Riemsdijk (1985) was the first to postulate such an intimate connection between CPP and the WC (although he did not express the relation in the way it was just put), and he notes that CPP and WC are in complementary distribution in German: CPP is possible with infinitives only (113) – which must not enter the WP. It is therefore tempting to account for W8 (the absence of infinitives in a WC) in terms of a blocking relation with (125). See Trissler (1999) for a recent pied-piping analysis of (125) and related constructions.

(125)
Wen zu küssen würde ein Fehler sein?
who to kiss would a mistake be
‘Who would it be a mistake to kiss?’
Being an instance of extended pied-piping, CPP does not fall under the term partial movement in the strict sense.
